content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
												WARNING: Potential Spoilers (Minor) Spread Throughout This ReviewOn Hardware/FPS issuesI'm going to be honest. I've seen a lot of people saying they're getting hard framerate issues with aparently high end rigs. Better than my rig, that's for sure. However, a lot of issues that others are having on better rigs aren't that bad on mine. I think that's a matter of tinkering with the game to get what you want out of it. While I don't hit 60 fps that other people can (occasionally), my fps is pretty stable, with it rarely ever dropping into an 'unplayable' state, and even when it does, it resolves itself rather quickly. This is running at fullscreen at 1600x900 resolution. I could probably get even better fps by putting it to a lowe resolution, but I find the framerate to be playable almost all the time. I feel that a large number of problems when it comes to the game's fps can be solved, or at least minimized, by just messing with the settings and seeing what works for your system. Remember that sometimes you can't just go by your specs (i.e. there's some games that I tend to run better with higher settings rather than with lower ones). Also, as dumb as it might sound, remember to close your other open programs when you're running a game that demands more out of your system. Freeing up RAM is extremely important, as the game will have more resources to work with when carrying out tasks(Just a note, I can't even run Skyrim at 60 fps [though it still runs with a stable framerate], yet I run FFXIII-2 better than a number of people who can. I don't know what it says about me or my machine, but it definitely says that the people complaining about technical problems could definitely do a bit of work on their own before blaming everything on the game)On Graphics  For reference, my game graphic settings are as follows:      Full-Screen Display Mode      1600x900 Resolution      512x512 Shadow Resolution      x2 Anti-aliasing (the minimum. I'd turn it off if I could)A number of people have complained about low resolution stuff. One in particular stated that the graphics all looked blurry above 1280x720p resolution. As I stated before, I run the game in full screen at 1600x900p and I don't get this at all. If anything, I would recommend turning down anti-aliasing (AA). It may sound counter-intuitive, but the point of AA is to smooth out images. If the texture resolutions are low, higher AA means it'll be trying to smooth textures even beyond what they 'need' (as dictated by the player), and can actually be the cause of blurry textures. Try turning AA down to fix the blurry texture problem if you seem to have that (As a plus, this can also improve your frame rate!)On Story/CharactersThere's a number of reviews on this matter, but a few in particular stuck out to me. One was about Serah's 'feminization', complaining how she's weaker than Noel, and more delicate/feminine, unlike her sister. First off, Serah's not really a fighter, she wasn't in the military like Lightning, and Noel survived in a wilderness. How can you expect her to match up to those? That's from a story perspective. In game, her stats aren't as high in strength, sure, but she has a higher magic stat and can perform just as well as noel in battle if you focus on building up her starting strength in magic. Don't forget class passives either, Commando gets a damage boost, if you have Noel Commando and Serah Ravager (like I did), of course Serah's not going to have as much damage output... initially. Don't forget that classes like the ravager can still target weak points that one like the commando can't, allowing them to gain even more damage output than even the commando's damage bonus gives.Sorry, got on a tangent there.A more common complaint is that the characters are flat, and the story is lacking as well.As far as characters go, I think the main reason for this complaint is that there simply aren't that many steady characters that you can compare Serah and Noel to. As characters, I think they're fine. The problem lies in that they're the only characters that remain constant. In a larger group / party of characters, such as in Final Fantasy XIII, there's a lot more variety in personality, allowing for a lot more dynamic in the group as a whole. With just two people, they can't cover as much ground as the larger group can, and so, they seem flat by comparison. That's my spin on the whole thing.As for story, one thing I've seen a few times is that it doesn't make sense for them to be jumping around at random to reach Lightning. My response is: They have no idea how to get to her beyond through the portals they're using. There's no set way to get into Valhalla (as far as I've seen in the game yet). Noel got there by a prayer, quite literally. There was some outside intervention that brought him there, and he has no idea how to do it on his own, aside from knowing that the portals are somehow the way there. What else CAN they do beyond working through this network of portals and hope they find the right one? Besides, them magically winding up on the proper portal early on makes for a short and boring game. If they had an easier way to it, then you can bet even more people would be complaining about the game being short.The rest of the story, how things play out and such. Early on, you don't get too much about the world. For one, the game IS a sequel, you're expected to have at least some basic prior knowledge of the world and its events before playing it. Even if you aren't, there's a system in the game DEDICATED to providing lore about the world around you. Even without prior knowledge, you can get a decent look at the world just by reading through the data logs. And besides, if you got all the information at the start, there's no mystery or intrigue. That makes for a far more boring game than a somewhat convulated story. At least a convulated story gives you something to think about as you play through it, rather than handing everything to you on a silver platter.There's a lot more I could say, but I'll leave it there for fear of this becoming a pure rant.My Personal ThoughtsOverall, I liked the game. I liked the characters, the world, the combat, everything. Though I may be somewhat biased, as I like the Final Fantasy games and Square Enix a lot. I'll admit, sometimes I do wish I could get higher frames, but that's mostly an issue of me finding the optimal setup, and my system IS somewhat bogged down by a variety of things. I'll admit, the game gets tedious at times, but that's to be expected of a JRPG.

												Gameplay's largely improved from the first game; paradigm system's a little more fleshed out, unwanted encounters are mostly easier to avoid, more to do, more open. Story has difficulty standing on its own, but I wouldn't necessarily say it's bad, just a lot of missed opportunities and overreliance on referencing the original. Interestingly it's the only time travel game I've seen to make use of string theory. As a port, there's a severe dearth of options. Resolution, shadows, AA, and that's about it. Textures in particular look very dated and can't be adjusted, so I'd suggest finding a third party tool to force antisotropic filtering. I didn't experience any stability or framerate issues, though there was some weird behavior with alt-tabbing that required the game to be restarted. Decent enough game for the price if you have a JRPG itch.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2014
												Please note that I am very familiar with FINAL FANTASY XIII-2 on the PS3, hence why my playtime may not seem that great.FINAL FANTASY XIII was a fairly ill-recieved game that dissapointed critics and fans alike, the Steam port of which was barrated for having next to no graphics options (thankfully, both ports now do) but it was no where near as bad as people thought. Long drawn out story, annoying characters, pesky bosses aside... it was a pretty eventful 50 hours, after which it's frankly boring narrative was summed up and we could all go home.Until now.FINAL FANTASY XIII-2 literally re-writes the ending of XIII, placing us in an entire new universe as Lightning's younger sister, Serah, and her charming companion, Noel. They join forces on a quest through time to save Lighting (who has now been erased from time. For some reason.) in the sequel that no one asked for - but it actually works.First thing first XIII-2 improves on alot of what XIII was lacking. Freedom is now a big part of the game, players can now choose what time zone to visit and what order they want the story to play out in - which is a very nice addition to the plot as it fuses well with the time-travel theme. The battle system remains similar, except a new feature has been added allowing you to add a monster you have collected into your party - sort of like Pokemon. You are free to customize the monster, and level it up with your party. This is a really neat feature, which opens up the battleground for new opportunities. However, this game comes across like it is trying to hard to be different from XIII. The narrative is convoluted and complicated - worse than the usual FINAL FANTASY formula. The different time zones and multiple (pointless) "Paradox" endings do not weave well with eachother, chances are you won't know what's going on half the time. However, unlike XIII you are thrown straight into the drama at the start of the game, no waiting about 20 hours for something to happen. And I do admit, some events in the plot did grab my attention - some of my fondest FF memories reside within XIII-2. The entire story does feel like a kick to the groin, as those 50 hours I spent in XIII are rendered pointless as almost none of it's key ideas are mentioned. You could easily pick this game up and go (it even has a plot summary of XIII.)Another feature I enjoyed of XIII-2 is The Coliseum, a battle area in which you fight off special monsters/bosses in order to win them for your moster collection. It's a pretty neat way to level up your party, or just to have a muck around in. Most of the battles are DLC - but luckily this port comes with most of the available DLCs including the 3 story expansion packs.All in all, FINAL FANTASY XIII-2 (like XIII) is not a bad game. It rights many of XIIIs wrongs, and certainly is a more enjoyable experience while a more confusing one.+ All DLC included. Mostly.+ Improves on many of FINAL FANTASY XIIIs flaws.+ Major improvement on XIII cast.+ New, enjoyable, characters.+ Moster collecting.+ Added freedom. Feels more like an RPG than any modern FINAL FANTASY.- Convoluted narrative.- Makes XIII feel pointless.- Cop-out ending. Sequel bait.- DLC stories unsatisfying.- Easy to exploit the level up system.- QTEs. *shivers*7/10

Posted: March 21, 2016
												If you found the original Final Fantasy XIII to be lacking and are hopeful you'll enjoy the redesigned second entry into the FF13 trilogy, be prepared for indifference. While FF13-2's battle and encounter system have been greatly improved, the flaws from FF13 are still present and hamper enjoyment of the game. The time travel element is welcome if you're, like me, a fan of the SNES classic Chrono Trigger, but wears out its welcome when it comes to collecting specific key items required to advance gameplay. You'll quickly grow tired of time-hopping in order to run across a regional map to pick up one item only to do the same thing in several other timelines. The plot is also a mixed bag and only mildly improves on its predecessor's writing, leaving me dreading the last quarter of the game or so which I only completed as I felt obligated to at that point. If you're already an FF13 fan, this game might be worth checking out otherwise avoid this game.

content:
Posted: September 30, 2016
												Definitely a step in the right direction from FF13, but there is still room for improvement...We are not completely free from corridors, character limitations (which goes step further actually, by giving you only two characters to play with (AND NONE OF THEM IS LIGHTNING?! Seriously, screw you SE...) and that's it! You can tame hundreds of monsters to fill up that third slot, sure, but it's not complete freedom, you know) or no-think combat, but the game is just too short to make these things unbearable. Which is not a bad thing; you can rush through main story in 30 or so hours and it won't be even that difficult to do it, but you can also choose to mess around, do side quests and explore areas and times  you won't get to in the main line (FF13-2 chose not to use areas from previous game, or at least not at main stage, but rather introduced time travel, so you can explore the same areas in different eras or even in alternate timelines. Which is kind of lazy, if you ask me, as you are at the exactly same spot like three times but once there is sun, other there's night and last it's snowy. And it counts as three different areas...). For that reason most of the encounters are pretty easy because you can literally trigger them at any point of the game.Minor spoilers ahead.So uh, story... How should I put it... FF13 had story but it took a long time to get through it. 13-2 is in story part kind of shallow... At the beginning you are introduced to your goal (and also a minor point that the ending you've seen in 13 is a lie, lol. What a way to build a sequel!), but when you ask anyone how to get there, they're all like; "Oh I don't know... Try going through this Time Gate and see if something happens..." So you go and wait until something actually happens (that doesn't take long, mind you) and you kill something that somehow prevents another Gate from being used and you go on. And when you finally somehow made it to your destination, you are told you're late and whole world is being destroyed because of it. And that's it! That's the whole story! No plot twists, just few minor bumps here and there that didn't even matter in the end...And don't even get me started on the conversations... I wanted to say it in FF13 review, but I reconsidered, however FF13-2 did it in so much bigger scale... Absolute most of the conversations are completely pointless, just to fill up awkward silence while you're waiting for something to happen! And what better thing to talk about than the reasons why you're on this journey?! I mean, first few times it's kind of bearable as those are new lore bits for the player. But I was sick of hearing the same; "For Lightning!", "For Hope!", "For the future!", "For the world!" and "You must not give up now!" over and over and over through the whole game!Spoilers end here.One point I criticized about FF13 is having no way to replay the story with your maxed out characters. In 13-2, areas are not connected in the game-world but only through Historia Crux (Crossroad of Time and Space), that means you can from there reset time in each particular location back to the point before you entered it for the first time! (I guess it might not be so big of a deal for most people but I really enjoy having the option to brutally kick asses of the first bosses)Which kind of leads me to another plus of this game; you get dialogue options! You can choose how your characters will respond, what they will ask about, what approach they'll take to a problem. And the time reset I mentioned allows you to go back and try out the other options you did not pick the first time and experience other challenges or even endings. Although it doesn't always cause much of a difference, it's still much better than the FF13 the Movie...Combat is pretty much similar, but it gets some depth in form of the monster partners as each one of them has some unique abilities but you can consume that monster and give that ability to another one and create super-killing machine (FEED ON YOUR FRIENDS AND GROW STRONGER MY MINIONS!).As I said in the beginning, this is definitely improved version of FF13. So much improved that it even might be worth paying for, how about that?! Just one thing to mention, the game expects you to know the events of FF13 and lore behind the world as it builds upon that. You have the option to read a summarized version of it's story in-game, but it's not too explaining about most of the side stuff and lore, so you might want to go through 13 first...Oh, and for those wondering; I played it on the same machine as FF13 and 13-2 had much better performance than that. I even sometimes hit 30 fps in small areas :P

content:
Posted: March 24, 2016
												WARNING, this is a recommendation with a huge list of "BUT"s and things you need to know and is very much not a glowing one. And first thing to know - do NOT play this game with steam cloud on, turn it off before you even start in the game library properties, otherwise the game will crash very often during "now loading" screens and attemtps to switch to offline saves mid-game will result in infinite loading screens for that game, unless switched back to cloud saves. Also, the game port is pretty buggy, you should search for a rain effect fix if you value your eyesight and the game will load like 1/5 times when you launch it, just keep trying.So after this lenghy "the port is horrible" opening let's get to the actual game. What's good about it is that it actually tries to use all those ideas found (and wasted) in Final Fantasy XIII properly and succeedes in many cases. All RPG systems and mechanics are still flawed, but are much more fun to play with, battles are less boring and actually require some thought and the progressions is rather open. The levels are no longer "go from point A to point B in a corridor" and while they're reused constantly with variations via the whole time traveling plot, they're mostly fun and look good. Game has a system similar to oldschool random encounters, which is both good and annoying. There are horrible puzzle sections, although they are ussually tied to optional areas and quests. And there are few super annoying and boring platforming sections, but the game is not too insane with those.What is also good is that the plot is happening. It's weird to put "this storydriven RPG has plot" as a plus, but after FF XIII that has nothing happening for dozens of hours, having things happen, story expand, characters develop all the time is great. The story itself is, like with FF XIII, more interesting in theory than in execution and few twists and turns feel not just silly but completely undermining some of the other stuff, but it has moments. And is surprisingly darker than you might expect. But overall, storytelling and themes are good, waaaay better than hours of nothing from FF XIII, even if a lot of stuff feels stupid or absurd and tone can be off by a lot.It looks good, it sounds very good, if sometimes unexpected (soundtrack switches from usual FF, to Resident Evil/Parasite Eve 2 feel (same composer), to Devil May Cry 3-4 in seconds and always catches you off guard). It has very welcome tweaks to UI and controls. It's a bit too experimental for it's own good. But it's also pretty fun. Not something to go into for a full price, especially with the port quality like this, but a pretty interesting jRPG nonetheless.

This isn't a problem for me, however I will say that it is not pushing my system to it's limits, as is normal for console ports these days.

												What will you expect from Final Fantasy XIII-2? (Strongly recommend to play through the previous game, CONTAINS SPOILERS FROM XIII)(TL,DR: Read Pros&Cons and Overall at the bottom, I played on the console version)„Why does mankind defy its fate?”The game takes place three years after the events of Final Fantasy XIII, and depicts the story of Serah Farron's journey across time and space to prevent the end of the world while searching for her missing sister, Lightning.Pros: - Fantastic atmosphere - The battle system expanded (you can catch monsters and they fight with you as third party member)- Epic music (more vocals and remixed versions for pre-battle)- ’More openworld’ than the XIII had, side missions, puzzles, casino etc.- Returning characters and places (You can visit the areas in other timelines, these areas change in appearance)- You can replay the chapters/missions anytime you want, and you can continue your journey (this is the NewGame+)- Paradox (or alternate) endings- Epic final boss battle with one of the best FF antagonist- You will get all the DLCs (3 story, all Coliseum battles, outfits)- Still an amazing story, but...Cons:- ...again linear and complicated (time travelling)- Only two playable characters (the DLCs grant you to play with Sazh, and Lightning in their own story)- Too easy- Shorter than XIIIStory (AF timeline means After the Fall of Cocoon):After the events of XIII, Lightning gets caught by a paradoxon and taken to Valhalla, the realm of death. While everybody thinks Lightning is dead, Serah is confident that her sister is alive. Lightning will be a knight of goddess Etro, and her task to save the future from Caius Ballad, who wants to destroy the time, he is Yeul's immortal Guardian and seeks to end the suffering she sustains by being endlessly reincarnated by killing the goddess Etro. Noel Kreiss comes from the Dying World at 700 AF, where he is the last surviving human in a world that faced destruction 200 years after the Crystal Pillar’s fall and Lightning ask him to find Serah and help her reach Valhalla. In New Bodhum (on Gran Pulse) at 3 AF Noel coming to find Serah. The two encounters in an epic journey through time and space to solve the paradoxons and save the world and Lightning. What about with the original team? Fang and Vanille are still in the Crystal Pillar, Hope is now 24 years old and the leader of the Academy (the new capital city), Sazh and Dajh have mysteriously gone missing, Snow left to search for Lightning two years after her disappearance, and Serah stayed with the NORA at New Bodhum.Battle:The battle system returns from XIII, you are able to switch the party leader during battle, the third party member will be a monster that will fight along with you with their own role (One monster = One role) and you can upgrade them (new abilites, better stats). It’s okay because three monsters can be held at a time, and automatically switch to the role a player shifts to in the paradigm. The Crystarium system returns too, with levels not with tiers. A new form of damage, called Wound Damage, lowers a target's member's max HP during battle and can only be healed by items, giving further incentive to defeat enemies as quickly as possible. If the current party leader is KO'd, the party leader is automatically switched to the other human character. The defeat of the human characters in the party results in a game over.Playtime (My first walkhthrough): Story: 32 hours (ofc with cutscenes)100%, All achievements, all (160) fragments, best chocobo for racing: 63 hoursOverall:For me this game 10/10, if I need to compare to the other FF games then 8/10, the story not better than the XIII’s story, but the atmosphere is better and the battles are exciting, there will be people who like this game more than the previous.If you loved the first installment, you will love this one too, if you hated you will be disappointed again, don’t buy it then. That's a pity, because I think it promises adventure not to be missed, despite its flaws.If you liked the game, I can recommend the finale of the trilogy: Lightning Returns.Thanks for reading!

												I recently gave Final Fantasy XIII a negative review, and was told that this one fixed many of the issues that that game had, and that it would be worth at least giving a try. So I did. Or I tried. What do I mean with "I tried?". Well, I tried to play it, but the port makes it unplayable.I can't make a rundown of the story, the gameplay or anything like that, because I've spent less than an hour with the game. The makers of this game seem to have taken the criticism of FF XIII having a far too long "tutorial" section to heart, and the bits of the game I could see felt a lot less railroaded, which are both things that would have been massive improvements. It did have a really long and uninteresting quick time event section though.Keys are partially re-bindable, but there are keys you can't rebind. Hope you like moving your hand between the numpad and backspace repeatedly, because you need to use the numpad for camera controls, and backspace for certain interactions, plus quick time event commands.Sadly the game does not work. At least not for me. The first issue I had was that the first menu that popped up after I had selected new game, which asked me if I wanted to play the tutorial or not, made the game completely unresponsive. There's a known issue with gamepads causing this issue, and it was also present in FF XIII, but my gamepad was not plugged in. Turned out I had to unplug my bog standard optical mouse, and my cellphone to get the game to respond (yes having a cellphone, a Samsung Galaxy S4 mini, plugged in for charging was enough to make the first menu not work).The second issue is massive stuttering. My computer exceeds the minimum system requirements by a wide margin, yet the game stutters constantly.After finally having got into the game, I noticed that whoever was responsible for the sound mixing had not done their job properly. I could not hear the dialogue due to the music being way to loud. Subtitles helped alleviate this issue, but it's still a rather big issue when you can't hear the character speak.And then the game crashed. Unceremoniously it just dumped me to the desktop with no error message.There might be a good game underneath all these technical issues, but this port is so bad that I'm unable to play the game. It's actually worse than the rather horrible port that FF XIII got.

Posted: May 27, 2015
												As you might recall, Final Fantasy XIII was pretty much reviled everywhere. As a response, Square-Enix released a sequel that promised to fix everything that was wrong with the previous game. Did it work?Yeah....sorta.The first thing that is immediately apparent with the game is that there is no longer any linearity.In fact, the game is the opposite of XIII, with both the story and game systems taking a free-form approach, allowing you to level your characters the way you want, and tackle the story chapters with quite a bit of degree of freedom, though this freedom also means there's some tedious back&forth in some sections.Speaking of story...it's still nonsensical, with a LOT of reading done through datalogs to get the gist of it,like XIII was.Liked it more than XIII, but that's mostly due to being a sucker for sci-fy plots (like time-travel), and for  That ending.Graphically, the game's a bit worse than XIII, but nothing serious that could distract you.Some places look just as great as XIII did (Academia looks pretty gorgeous). Graphical Settings are a exact carbon copy from XIII, with nothing to set both of 'em apart in that regard (patch for XIII released at the same time as this released). The performance did change though...for the worse. This game runs even worse than XIII did, on the exact same hardware.I usually don't mention audio, but Final Fantasy games in general are known to have good soundtracks, and XIII & XIII-2 are no exceptions. Special mention goes to that ridiculous chocobo metal song, it's just too silly to not like it!So, the tl,dnr: improved sequel marred yet again by performance issues. Buy it if you're a fan &/or is on sale.PS: Same regional restrictions that applied to XIII applies here. Asian version is restricted to the Asian region.Get the Western version if you want an unrestricted version.(Source: https://steamdb.info/sub/41113/ )PSS: Squeenix...Lightning Returns when?

content:
Posted: December 16, 2014
												This is the game FF13 should have been. It's almost amazing how well Square Enix managed to improve upon FF13 while maintaining it's core principles and mechanics.Gameplay is an improved version of FF13's paradigm/ATB combat. You still have the same roles (COM, RAV, SAB, SYN, MED, SEN) and the same maximum of 3 members in your party. Except now you have the ability to get rare drops from almost everything you fight (excluding bosses) that allow you to use said monster for your 3rd party member. This really opens up that much needed flexibility, compared to FF13 where all 6 party members were essentially the same apart from their full ATB skill. Also important to note is that there's no longer a long animation for paradigm shifting, which really feels more natural and doesn't make your characters idle for a few seconds, wasting that precious time you could be using to input commands. Characters feel less clunky and slow in their animations and you get the full combat system available very early on into the story. One of the main gripes I had with FF13 was that you were forced into the slow progression into unlocking the full capabilities of the paradigm shifting system. Other than the reasonable improvements, it's still essentially FF13's combat mechanics. You still craft higher tier-weapons with monster materials, although it's less farmy compared to FF13. Accessories take a major backseat due to a limitation being placed on the amount of accessories you can hold on one character, which different accessories having different amounts of capacity they take up. Eidolons/Summons are gone, but it's not really missed since you'd barely use them in FF13 anyway. You also get Fragment Skills, which are unlocked as you go along completing the game. These have a wide range of effects from changing monster encounter rates to opening up different endings by allowing an alternative path.The world itself has been really revamped though. You can now jump (although you're often blocked with invisible walls in most places) and as a result, there's a lot more verticality in the map design. You aren't forced into a corridor driving you forward towards the story. Progression is done by visiting areas of varying sizes, some small, some very large, in different time periods. You'll often have the option of visiting a place multiple times in different time periods, but it's not repetitive due to the slightly altered designs and different npcs. FF13-2 still has that gorgeous visual quality from FF13. The level design really has an emphasis on creating the perfect atmosphere for the situation, It's amazing how well they managed to convey each time period of the same location so uniquely.The story's done much better, with excellent pacing that feels natural and not forced. You unlock new locations (and time periods of that said location) within a level and progress slowly along with the story, although the locations have barely any correlation with each other. The story itself is actually done well. Characters feel natural and likable, and the main antagonist is one of the best Final Fantasy villians in recent memory. Pacing is done well since you control where and when to go and it's fairly open. It feels more like you're just going around places solving time paradoxes and moving onto the next world, which is a really nice change from FF13's forced pacing. There's plenty of optional areas to visit during the story, and the hub (Historia Crux) allows you to visit past areas instantly without having to retrace your steps. Sonically, this is personally one of my favourites from the recent FF games. There's FF13 tracks, remixed FF13 tracks and new music that really helps set the tone of the game. There's beautiful orchestral tracks, well written vocals and context appropriate background music that help drive the atmosphere of each and every situation. Although I felt there were a bit too many vocals and it was definite far more than what's usually present in a FF game. Not that I'm complaining though, some of the vocal tracks are done perfectly. Naoshi Mizuta outdoes herself in Noel's Theme, which features hauntingly sombre vocals, with a simple piano and violin background. The song really encompasses the character Noel and his struggles, and it's used to really emphasise emotional scenes. The main battle theme, Paradigm Shift, is a fast paced track featuring a vibrant violin, a simple but strong drum beat and a bassy synth. It really suits the frantic but orderly nature of battles and it's colourful but subdued enough to help focus on the battle. Eclipse is another standout, with vocals acting as a backing to the sharp violins, frantic pianos and punchy bassline. Honestly, even if my terrible adjectives haven't convinced you, at least listen to the soundtrack. It's really good.As a PC port, it's bad. Not FF13 bad, but still pretty bad. It has graphical options for resolution, anti-aliasing and shadow resolutions but nothing else. And it's not even ingame, but within a window that acts as a launcher of sorts. The EscKey=AltF4 is still here with it's warning box that's STILL a popup box outside of the game. It's 60fps, but poorly optimised so you can expect sudden drops in certain areas. Graphically, it's stunning but with few options to tinker around with. There hasn't been any bugs I've noticed though, compared to FF13 which suffered from random crashes that forced you to save at every available opportunity. As PC ports go, Square Enix still has a long way to go.All in all, it's a good game with great visuals, an interesting time-travel based story with an optimised combat system from FF13 and a very memorable OST. Better than FF13 in every way. Easily get it if you're a fan of jRPGs, it's an excellent choice.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
												You played FFXIII and want to know if this one is worth playing?  That depends on what you did and didn't like about XIIII'll compare the two games some to give you an idea of how the sequel changed up the formula.Linearity:XIII-2 is much more open than the first game.  Each area can be explored and has hidden objects to discover, there are also occasionally different enemy types for different parts the zones.  There are less unique locations than the first game, but I think the openness of the areas makes up for it.Party members:  There are 2.  The first game had 6 characters to choose from and while many parts forced you into specific configurations of party members, there were times that you had a choice of how to compose your party.  XIII-2 only has two human party members and the third slot is for monster party members that you capture and level up sort of like pokemon.  There is quite a bit of depth to this mechanic, but I still would have liked some extra speaking party members.Combat:  Largely unchanged.  Big improvements are the ability to continue fighting a battle when your party leader dies, and the ability to change leader mid-battle.  Some of the SAB and SYN abilities appear to be missing, making those roles a bit more simplified(Those skills may be present in monster party members that I haven't used yet)  Monsters are not sitting out of the world in this game, at least for the most part.  They act more like the random encounters of older JRPGs, with the exception that you can still occasionally avoid them after they have spawned by running away.  I feel like this is a better system because it mostly prevents you from farming a single enemy over and over like the optimal CP grind in the first game which ultimately led to me giving up on its endgame. Crafting:  I disliked the crafting system in the previous game, largely because it wouldn't tell you which items were required to improve weapons, and it had no indicator to show when a piece of equipment was at it's max level or could be upgrading another rank.  XIII-2 has solved these problems but also has a much simpler system which lost some of the depth that could have been.  A vendor sells you new weapons in exchange for crafting materials and occasionally an old weapon too.  Story:I found FFXIII's story to be enjoyable but also easily forgettable.  I didn't think any of the characters were well written or very likable(except for maybe Saszh) and only a few months later I barely remember any of the major plotpoints.  XIII-2 is much the same case, There are parts of the story that I liked, but the character dialogue was mostly bland and often grating.  In particular I found one of the main characters very unlikable, and with no option to remove him from my party I had to play the entire game with him.Endgame:  I find that I am enjoying XIII-2's end game much more than that of the previous game.  The path to max level is almost over and I have just been going around doing quests for fragments with barely any true grinding. There is a lot to do with the monster party members that I have not done yet; that appears like it could get grindy later on.  I haven't fought any of the hardest bosses in either game yet, but for XIII-2 I do think I will end up doing that, while I don't know if I can stand the grind in XIII long enough to get there.New Things:Puzzles:  There are some puzzles that are required to be completed in certain areas, and for the most part I found these ranged for boring and unenjoyable to frustrating and unenjoyable.  I think at this point that I've finished all of the puzzles in the game, and I didn't find one of them to be enjoyable at all, and I enjoy playing puzzle games occasionally.Hidden objects:  There are a lot of hidden objects to find in the game for 100% completion.  Fragments are mostly tied to quests but occasionally hidden throughout the game world.  There is an indicator to show you how many you are missing in a particular area, and I've been enjoying hunting these down.  I find them much more interesting than the less varied Ci'eth stone missions from the first game.Then there are the wild artefacts which I ended up hating.  These are hidden objects that must be found to access certain areas.  Most of them I found during regular play, but after beating the game I still had a few that I hadn't found, and with no indicator hinting at which zone they might be in, I had to mindlessly comb every area I had been to looking for the last few.  I finally did manage to find them all, but I found the task very frustrating.  It feels like the developers might have been assuming that players would just go online for a guide for these, but I prefer to avoid outside assistance when possible.Overall I enjoy it and if you enjoyed the first game you may very well enjoy this one as well.  It still has many of the flaws that drove away hardcore Final Fantasy fans, but some of those were fixed.

												Chocolina and Mog.  Possibly the only redeeming qualities of XIII-2.  Okay and maybe the music.  XIII was a full, flagship title game; XIII-2 and LR feel like they were created by a third-party using assets that were not included in the original XIII.  The developers even stated in interviews that they had enough material leftover from XIII to create another game.  Well, guess what, this is what you get; sloppy story written to fit the usable assets rather than build assets for a decent story.  Time travel can be an excellent tool in storytelling but it can also be an excuse for developers to reuse the same environment but give it a different name.  They did try to make this game seem appealing, and it would be, for, say, people who have never played a above average RPG.  While I did not run into many issues other players have reported a number of issues with the port on the community hub page.  Sadly as a whole the experience was not very memorable for me but for someone new to FF - maybe.  And cripes would it have killed them to change or even modify the model of the treasure spheres?? Pros: a) Mog & Chocolinab) You can throw mogc) You get to see all the assets that could have been in XIIId) Cinematic cutscenese) Couple of nice music tracksCons:a) Messy story (if you were expecting romance, sorry to disappoint)b) Barely any Lightningc) Few new monsters (reused the same models/animations from XIII)d) Gimmicks/time sinks in place of good storytelling (coliseum, casino, quizzes, weather changes, 100% map collection)e) Changes as a result of time travel not tied to the main story are superficial, no significance, minimal impact (you don't get to see the results of the change and quite frankly aren't given many opportunities to make change)f)  Spawn rates are far too frequent to let you just enjoy the game; you never become truly immersedg) lazy end game; at one point it literally turns into a platformer with respawn by falling into void space (FML) h) Poor character development

content:

												It's time!I can't say I expected much after the dissapointment that was Final Fantasy XIII.But I ended up enjoying this game a lot more than the original.If you want to read my review for the original XIII :  Link Time for pros and cons:Pros: +The game is no longer a long corridor, the areas are open with things to be discovered and time travel gives a good excuse to see many diverse and interesting locations. There is a nice amount of different locations and some areas are the same location but in a different time period.+Good music overall and some tracks are superb. Like these:  Paradigm Shift   Noel's Theme+The narrative is very focused compared to the muddled mess in the original. This is mostly thanks to there only being a handful of main characters.+The villian is great, you completely understand why he is doing the things he does.+The combat is a lot better this time around while still feeling like the same system:     +When you changed your partys roles in the orignal game there was a animation that took you out of the battle for about 2         seconds, this might not seem like a big deal but removing this animation and just letting the battle flow like it was before does a lot to improve the pacing of fights in this game.     +If the character you are controlling dies you just take control of the other person in your party. This was lacking in the  original game and it is very nice to see them address this problem.      +You can also change what character you are controlling mid battle, a very welcome addition.+The leveling system is actually very open to customization compared to the linear mess in the original. If you want to you could go through the entire game without ever getting the ability to heal. Not that I would reccomend it but it's awesome that you can do that.+You have 2 characters that are stuck in your party and a third slot open for a monster that you have tamed. You can tame most of the monsters in the game and every monster has its own abilites and base stats. I say base stats because you could have 2 "Behemoth" monsters but level them up completely differently. You can also find a lot of cosmetic items for the monsters, including hats. Each monster also has a unique limit break ability.+There is loads of optional content. Through the story you will be collecting "Fragments" to unlock new locations and time periods. You get these items by doing side quests and just finding them in chests. When I finished the game I only had 36 out of 160. So if you want to, you could spend a lot of time with this game.+This time around they included some actual graphics options. Including resolution, MSAA up to 16x and shadow resolution.+The game CAN run at 60 fps but...+There is dual audio, I played it in english and everyone was fine except for Lightning. She has less peronality than Microsoft Sam. Good thing Lightning only has about 10 minutes of screentime in the entire game.+Weapon system is better than in the original. In the original you could upgrade your weapons meaning that if you just kept upgrading your original weapon you had no reason to ever buy a new one. And because of the effort and gil needed to upgrade a single weapon you literally had no reason to ever get a new weapon. In this one you get access to new weapons in the shop the further you progress in the game, some are just a straight up upgrade, stat wise anyway. But other weapons have special abilites stuck to them but these require some additional items aswell as gil to be bought. All in all it's a straightforward system but at least it works, unlike the original.+Game leads nicely into XIII-3.Cons: -Time travel elements are very "It's magic I ain't got to explain♥♥♥♥♥♥quot;, but then the characters waste a lot of time in cutscenes talking about how it works and it just ends up wasting time.-The combat is still very much a case of just switching your classes to match the situation and pressing the "Auto" button. There was only one time in the game where I actually selected commands and that was because I was against an enemy that had health regen but my character refused to cast poison with auto.-You can't control your characters in battles. This can be really annoying in a lot of different sittuations, like when you have somebody as a tank with the ability to divert enemy attention to themselves and the party just stands around really close to each other, as a result everyone gets hit regardless. This defeats the entire purpose of a system that works in a 3D space.-Story was okay at best but a lot of time was wasted on nonsensical time travel ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t and in the end it just came down to "X thing is a paradox, we must kill/fix it!". X often being just a random boss enemy in the area. The story was more interesting when it focused on the stories of Ciaus, Yuel, Serah and Noel.-The game has very unstable framerate. I never dropped under 30 though, nonetheless it can be very annoying to watch as the framerate jumps all over the place.- The game crashed at least once every 2 hours. The biggest time lost as a result was 1 hour. Regardless, this was very annoying and by doing a short google search I can see that I am not the only one with this issue.-This time around there are minigames, something lacking from the original but all of them are luck based and some are even locked behind DLC. Conclusion:I must admit I wasn't excpecting much out of this game but all the non-linearity and freedom came as a big surprise.With loads of optional content, much improved combat system and non-linearity in almost every aspect, this game is actually worth playing unlike the original. As long as you are fine with a combat system that is very simplistic and a story that makes little to no sense.I will likely edit this review soon if I forgot to talk about something.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
												You played FFXIII and want to know if this one is worth playing?  That depends on what you did and didn't like about XIIII'll compare the two games some to give you an idea of how the sequel changed up the formula.Linearity:XIII-2 is much more open than the first game.  Each area can be explored and has hidden objects to discover, there are also occasionally different enemy types for different parts the zones.  There are less unique locations than the first game, but I think the openness of the areas makes up for it.Party members:  There are 2.  The first game had 6 characters to choose from and while many parts forced you into specific configurations of party members, there were times that you had a choice of how to compose your party.  XIII-2 only has two human party members and the third slot is for monster party members that you capture and level up sort of like pokemon.  There is quite a bit of depth to this mechanic, but I still would have liked some extra speaking party members.Combat:  Largely unchanged.  Big improvements are the ability to continue fighting a battle when your party leader dies, and the ability to change leader mid-battle.  Some of the SAB and SYN abilities appear to be missing, making those roles a bit more simplified(Those skills may be present in monster party members that I haven't used yet)  Monsters are not sitting out of the world in this game, at least for the most part.  They act more like the random encounters of older JRPGs, with the exception that you can still occasionally avoid them after they have spawned by running away.  I feel like this is a better system because it mostly prevents you from farming a single enemy over and over like the optimal CP grind in the first game which ultimately led to me giving up on its endgame. Crafting:  I disliked the crafting system in the previous game, largely because it wouldn't tell you which items were required to improve weapons, and it had no indicator to show when a piece of equipment was at it's max level or could be upgrading another rank.  XIII-2 has solved these problems but also has a much simpler system which lost some of the depth that could have been.  A vendor sells you new weapons in exchange for crafting materials and occasionally an old weapon too.  Story:I found FFXIII's story to be enjoyable but also easily forgettable.  I didn't think any of the characters were well written or very likable(except for maybe Saszh) and only a few months later I barely remember any of the major plotpoints.  XIII-2 is much the same case, There are parts of the story that I liked, but the character dialogue was mostly bland and often grating.  In particular I found one of the main characters very unlikable, and with no option to remove him from my party I had to play the entire game with him.Endgame:  I find that I am enjoying XIII-2's end game much more than that of the previous game.  The path to max level is almost over and I have just been going around doing quests for fragments with barely any true grinding. There is a lot to do with the monster party members that I have not done yet; that appears like it could get grindy later on.  I haven't fought any of the hardest bosses in either game yet, but for XIII-2 I do think I will end up doing that, while I don't know if I can stand the grind in XIII long enough to get there.New Things:Puzzles:  There are some puzzles that are required to be completed in certain areas, and for the most part I found these ranged for boring and unenjoyable to frustrating and unenjoyable.  I think at this point that I've finished all of the puzzles in the game, and I didn't find one of them to be enjoyable at all, and I enjoy playing puzzle games occasionally.Hidden objects:  There are a lot of hidden objects to find in the game for 100% completion.  Fragments are mostly tied to quests but occasionally hidden throughout the game world.  There is an indicator to show you how many you are missing in a particular area, and I've been enjoying hunting these down.  I find them much more interesting than the less varied Ci'eth stone missions from the first game.Then there are the wild artefacts which I ended up hating.  These are hidden objects that must be found to access certain areas.  Most of them I found during regular play, but after beating the game I still had a few that I hadn't found, and with no indicator hinting at which zone they might be in, I had to mindlessly comb every area I had been to looking for the last few.  I finally did manage to find them all, but I found the task very frustrating.  It feels like the developers might have been assuming that players would just go online for a guide for these, but I prefer to avoid outside assistance when possible.Overall I enjoy it and if you enjoyed the first game you may very well enjoy this one as well.  It still has many of the flaws that drove away hardcore Final Fantasy fans, but some of those were fixed.

content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
												Chocolina and Mog.  Possibly the only redeeming qualities of XIII-2.  Okay and maybe the music.  XIII was a full, flagship title game; XIII-2 and LR feel like they were created by a third-party using assets that were not included in the original XIII.  The developers even stated in interviews that they had enough material leftover from XIII to create another game.  Well, guess what, this is what you get; sloppy story written to fit the usable assets rather than build assets for a decent story.  Time travel can be an excellent tool in storytelling but it can also be an excuse for developers to reuse the same environment but give it a different name.  They did try to make this game seem appealing, and it would be, for, say, people who have never played a above average RPG.  While I did not run into many issues other players have reported a number of issues with the port on the community hub page.  Sadly as a whole the experience was not very memorable for me but for someone new to FF - maybe.  And cripes would it have killed them to change or even modify the model of the treasure spheres?? Pros: a) Mog & Chocolinab) You can throw mogc) You get to see all the assets that could have been in XIIId) Cinematic cutscenese) Couple of nice music tracksCons:a) Messy story (if you were expecting romance, sorry to disappoint)b) Barely any Lightningc) Few new monsters (reused the same models/animations from XIII)d) Gimmicks/time sinks in place of good storytelling (coliseum, casino, quizzes, weather changes, 100% map collection)e) Changes as a result of time travel not tied to the main story are superficial, no significance, minimal impact (you don't get to see the results of the change and quite frankly aren't given many opportunities to make change)f)  Spawn rates are far too frequent to let you just enjoy the game; you never become truly immersedg) lazy end game; at one point it literally turns into a platformer with respawn by falling into void space (FML) h) Poor character development

content:
Posted: July 18, 2015
												FFXIII-2 got the changes that people wanted from FFXIII.  -Less linear -you can actually spec your characters while leveling them up-change leaders in the middle of a fight which means you no longer lose the fight if the leader dies.-enemies randomly appear rather than already being there-premptive strikes are a lot easier and make more sense-introduced paradigm save slotsThe only major downside was the total nerf of the Synergist role and how you applied buffs.  -Haste is no longer a castable spell but rather a bonus for getting a premptive strike, some items also apply it.  They also added aoe buffs which I guess balances it out.-The two main characters do not have any offensive buffs you can only get them from your monsters or their feral links.-removed fortisols-accessories are restricted, each one has a numeral cost.-some of the accesories got absolutely dirt nerfed.Overal I like FFXIII-2 just as much as the first.  It feels more fast paced in both the story and the gameplay.  The only thing you might have some problems with are finding some good monsters to level up in your party, especially early game.

content:
Posted: July 18, 2015
												FFXIII-2 got the changes that people wanted from FFXIII.  -Less linear -you can actually spec your characters while leveling them up-change leaders in the middle of a fight which means you no longer lose the fight if the leader dies.-enemies randomly appear rather than already being there-premptive strikes are a lot easier and make more sense-introduced paradigm save slotsThe only major downside was the total nerf of the Synergist role and how you applied buffs.  -Haste is no longer a castable spell but rather a bonus for getting a premptive strike, some items also apply it.  They also added aoe buffs which I guess balances it out.-The two main characters do not have any offensive buffs you can only get them from your monsters or their feral links.-removed fortisols-accessories are restricted, each one has a numeral cost.-some of the accesories got absolutely dirt nerfed.Overal I like FFXIII-2 just as much as the first.  It feels more fast paced in both the story and the gameplay.  The only thing you might have some problems with are finding some good monsters to level up in your party, especially early game.

Posted: May 13, 2015
												Awesome title from Square, even though the port could've been a little bit better, but still, the experience is there...(sidenote: I've beaten both FFXIII and FFXIII-2 first on Xbox and now on PC)Mechanics: IMO Better than FFXIII; Everything feels more responsive while switching paragims and selecting abilities (it was veery restricive in FFXIII, to that extend, that I was thinking about modding it for the sake of beating Long Gui) there are still some balance issues and, if you plan the whole development of your characters beforehand, you will end up with killing everything in one salvo without stagger, srsly, if you want the challenge later on in the game, try mods that increase HP, Strength and Mana of all enemies (google "FFXIII-2 Difficulty Enhancement Mod"). Oh, and the +50% ATB rate weapons are OP, totally OP. Since you get them, there isn't anything else worth looking when it comes to weapons (MAYBE +1 ATB weapons for that 6 ATB segments action lol)Story: Interesting, yet somewhat disappointing and too short for my taste (when this game was coming out, I was hoping for the title that would be like FFX-2 was to FFX). Tbh I liked FFXIII's story better despite its linear feel, but it does not mean FFXIII-2 sucks in that regard. It has some awesome and funny moments, plus you decide what to do next (you can techically get ~140 fragments before beating the main plot, but that would make the final boss battle laughable considering the amount of CP you will acumulate throughout the game). Overall, it's damn dark compared to the first title and, let's be honest, how many FFs are there where the "bad guys" actually win?As for the DLCs, PLAY'EM! the boss battles are a lot better than the main story (read "more difficult").Replayability: The amount of combinations that there is when it comes to Serah/Noel stats is just astonishing. Every player is able to create his/her own, unique character setup with the new CP system, that does not make your characters unstoppable. Each development strategy has its strenghts and weaknesses, and leads to different late game scenario, which is shaped by person's individual needs when progerssing though the game, A BIG PLUS for that.Is this game better than FFXIII? In some ways, yesDo I like it? YESIs it my favorite FF? Nope, that title goes to FFXWould I recomment it? If you've played FFXIII and liked it, ABSOLUTELYScore:chocobo/10

content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												Somewhat bland.  The story's forced and doesn't make logical sense. It's a grim reminder that "time travel is really hard to write about *sobs*" (--Dean Pelton).  The combat system is as monotonous as the first game in the 13 series and I nodded off quite a few times.  The levelling curve was also awkward with several areas consisting of enemies I can barely kill and then all of a sudden every boss encounter I have lasts barely 10 seconds.  There's quite a few boss fights that are just cheesy and have instantkill mechanics.  Aside from those, most of the boss fights are simplistic.  The game essentially doesn't respect the time of the player, makes progression quite vague, and involves a lot of walking back and forth, which may explain why I ended up outlevelling the content.  My opinion of this game may be clouded by how good Chrono Trigger was by comparison.  If you take the awful bits of Chrono Cross and cram it into a game, you essentially get FF13-2.Gameplay: 2.5/5Story: 2/5Music: 3/5Fun: 2/5PS:  One thing I really liked was the concept of Paradox Endings.  It's nice to have a game that lets you "fail" and see the consequences.  This is somewhat from Chrono Trigger as well but takes a lot less time for the most part to execute.

content:
Posted: October 2, 2015
												It's imperative you do research before purchasing this game, unfortunately. Look on the Steam forums for potential hardware issues (AMD CPU/GPU owners especially) and only decide after reading around. Depending on your rig, this game either works fine or with a tonne of issues (if at all). Sadly, I am in the latter group.However, the game itself is really enjoyable. I originally played it on the PlayStation 3 so I have prior and relevent experience with it. It is a relatively easy game as far as Final Fantasy titles go - even moreso if you're a well-seasoned RPGer and spend a lot of time exp grinding / farming. Aside from the main content of the story, there are quite a few additional things you can amuse yourselves with: chocobo racing, completing the monster log, slot machines, additional areas to explore, min-maxing pets and of course, the PC version comes with all of the DLC included.The environments are varied and interesting, full of colour and detail. In addition to the main characters, you're able to capture and train a pet for the third party slot. They will fulfil a specific role (Medic, Saboteur, Ravager etc.) and you can build paradigm sets to suit your play style.FFXIII-2 is designed with casual play in mind, I believe. There's a catch-up cutscene every time you load a previously-saved game, to remind you of your progress in the main story missions. This game also has, in my opinion, one of the best Final Fantasy soundtracks in recent years.Worth a try, certainly. If you can get it working properly.

content:
Posted: May 13, 2015
												Awesome title from Square, even though the port could've been a little bit better, but still, the experience is there...(sidenote: I've beaten both FFXIII and FFXIII-2 first on Xbox and now on PC)Mechanics: IMO Better than FFXIII; Everything feels more responsive while switching paragims and selecting abilities (it was veery restricive in FFXIII, to that extend, that I was thinking about modding it for the sake of beating Long Gui) there are still some balance issues and, if you plan the whole development of your characters beforehand, you will end up with killing everything in one salvo without stagger, srsly, if you want the challenge later on in the game, try mods that increase HP, Strength and Mana of all enemies (google "FFXIII-2 Difficulty Enhancement Mod"). Oh, and the +50% ATB rate weapons are OP, totally OP. Since you get them, there isn't anything else worth looking when it comes to weapons (MAYBE +1 ATB weapons for that 6 ATB segments action lol)Story: Interesting, yet somewhat disappointing and too short for my taste (when this game was coming out, I was hoping for the title that would be like FFX-2 was to FFX). Tbh I liked FFXIII's story better despite its linear feel, but it does not mean FFXIII-2 sucks in that regard. It has some awesome and funny moments, plus you decide what to do next (you can techically get ~140 fragments before beating the main plot, but that would make the final boss battle laughable considering the amount of CP you will acumulate throughout the game). Overall, it's damn dark compared to the first title and, let's be honest, how many FFs are there where the "bad guys" actually win?As for the DLCs, PLAY'EM! the boss battles are a lot better than the main story (read "more difficult").Replayability: The amount of combinations that there is when it comes to Serah/Noel stats is just astonishing. Every player is able to create his/her own, unique character setup with the new CP system, that does not make your characters unstoppable. Each development strategy has its strenghts and weaknesses, and leads to different late game scenario, which is shaped by person's individual needs when progerssing though the game, A BIG PLUS for that.Is this game better than FFXIII? In some ways, yesDo I like it? YESIs it my favorite FF? Nope, that title goes to FFXWould I recomment it? If you've played FFXIII and liked it, ABSOLUTELYScore:chocobo/10

content:
Posted: January 17, 2016
												Quality of port: very bad, low fps, needs to be heavily adjusted by the user to get any sort of quality out of, assuming thats even possible for casual users. The quick-time events are all coded in keyboard keys, but if you switch to an xbox controller, it doesn't give you an option to change it to xbox symbols, so you are left to figure out wtf backspace is on your controller. Quality of game: had me at first. thought it had a really interesting concept, but after i progressed through the game, it turned into one of the most tedious and frustrating things ive ever played. Key items you NEED to have in order to progress are hidden away in some of the most unintelligible and impossible locations. If you are going to have super difficult to find items hidden away in your game, DO NOT MAKE THEM ITEMS YOU NEED IN ORDER TO PROGRESS. I can almost 100% guarentee you that no one will complete this game without a walkthrough or a love for grinding. That or maybe getting lucky. If may not have been as straight-forward as the first installment, giving you a bit of freedom, but its at the cost of the game being extremely tedious and downright impossible at timesAdditional thoughts on game: level-up and role system was dummed down and poorly explained. Crystalarium expansion or what ever its called had intesting upgrades though. Combat through out this game was either so freaking easy i never needed to heal, i would just stay in relentless assault and kill everything in 1-2 turns without grinding, or it would be downright impossible. FF13-1 was way harder, but there were strategies to beating difficult enemies and it didn't ALWAYS come down to just grinding more, there were usually a few work-arounds. This game is all about just being stronger because some enemies will just be too hard to take down, period. I find it hard to believe this game came out not that long ago. It feels and plays like a game from 2008. Hard to believe games like skyrim came out around 2 years before this, when by comparison, i'd guess they were ten years apart, skyrim being the newest.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2015
												**Warning: Contains minor spoilers**Final Fantasy XIII-2 is one of those games where you spend hours doing stuff, but you usually don't really know what you're doing, or why you're doing it. Later, you find out, and the game gets more interesting.This game has some differences from the first part of trilogy, and it's got a nice pace. However, playing FF13-2 felt like I was playing a game that is completely unrelated to FF13.I can't put my finger on it, but something was bothering throughout the game. Don't get me wrong - I liked it, I liked it a lot. It's different than many FF titles in more than one way, but at the same time - it felt as if it's not really a Final Fantasy game. More like a game that borrows characters and some things from Final Fantasy, but is an individual game.The plot is weird, we all know that. Everything is in some kind of time-chaos, which leaves us to fix everything through lots of action, FMV sequences and dialogues. That's what we love about Final Fantasy, right? I liked the plot and the character progression. What I hated was the fact that I had very little chance to play with FF13 characters, since everything was revolving around the newcomer and Light's sister. Another thing I didn't like about the game was the limited focus on Alyssa's character, so her development seems a bit forced.The Battle system is very similar to FF13's, so everyhing is great until you come to the "Cinematic Action" parts of the game. It's frustrating and annoying, and should've stayed a feature in one of those old Spider-Man games. It has no place in a Final Fantasy title IMHO. Action is cool, and the battle-animations are great. Again, I would love to have seen more of the original FF13 cast, but Noel and Serah did a fine job too.Now that Lightning Returns has come to steam too, I will finally be able to finish this trilogy, and this makes me very happy. Playing through Final Fantasy XIII-2 left me with mixed feelings. Final Fantasy 13 is a game that I will surely play again some day, but I'm not sure I want to play 13-2 ever again. I'll be honest and say that I finished this game just for the story, and was not too interested in many of the side-quests (although I did some).Final Fantasy XIII-2 is a nice filler between FF13 and Lightning Returns, but playing this game I couldn't get rid of the "sequel syndrome". It's good, but not as good as FF13. I recommend the game to any Final Fantasy fan, and I think that players who are new to FF will like it as well.Don't play it if you love Counter Strike, Black Ops and Fallout. It's not that type of game, and you probably won't like it at all.My score: 8.2/10

Posted: October 24, 2016
												First of all do yourself a big favor and turn off Cloud save syncing. The game will most likely crash often when you try to save unless it's off. The game is also locked at 30fps unless you download a fan made fix. There are definitely slowdowns during gameplay if you use this, and voices can come out of sync as a result since lip-sync is not directly tied to framerate - a horrible mistake imo.If you somehow can look past these pretty bad flaws, there's a game here that much better than FF XIII, with a soundtrack that's both great and laughingly bad. This time you're able to tame monsters which is actually great fun. There are way more side missions and optional paths this time around and you can even go choboco racing. As for the story, well it's pretty convoluted to say the least. Highly simplified one can say that: Serah, Lightning's sister in the first game got saved from her crystal stasis at the end of FF XIII. However, Lightning has somehow disappeared. Serah along with a time travelling dude named Noel Kreiss agrees to go looking for her. And they do that by travelling through time.In short, it's a mixed bag. It has interesting mechanics, a story and gameplay that's better that FF XIII, but a soundtrack that leaves some things to be desired. I'm looking at you, death metal chocobo song. However you can't look away from the horrible load times, semi-frequent crashes and bad framerate. Pick this up only if you can cope with the shortcomings - some downright unacceptable and puzzling for a pc port taken into account that FF XIII did not have any of these issues.Do I recommend FF XIII-2? Yes.Do I recommend this port? No.Rating: 4/10

												I will talk about game play  This is the first and Olney final fantasy game I have played. The game play has two  major game play  elements   the battles  which you can actually do on an auto battle system .  where your sitting there pushing the  A button on your x box controller or whatever . until a quick time event where you have to  push a  series of buttons in sequence  and some areas have puzzles that you have to solve .       This game  can go on pretty much almost forever,  As you can travel back and forth between   areas  and after you get the main ending There are at least two mini games available to you if not more.   so a lot of content in this game .   However some areas the  battles get repetitive and annoying at times  showing the same  animated graphics sequences over and over again. and   some of the puzzles take a long time to solve this is not a short game .  It has really nice graphics  and good voice acting  I found the easy battle system to be an advantage  as I liked to drink while playing this and eye hand coordination was not an issue with the exception of the quick time events.  .There are also  NPC's that ask you to find various things for them and you have to go back and forth through the time line to  get them. For the most part however these are not mandatory items. For  getting the standard ending with the exception of  gravitational cores. and wild artifacts     Check your  computer system with the spec's on this this page  in the negative reviews there is a lot of people complaining that they can not run the game I had no problem with this .    Should you buy this game  I would wait for a sale though it does have a lot of content It is an older game, From other negative reviews it seems that  It was simply moved from  the old game play system  with very little to adapt it to  pc's   As I said I was lucky and had no problems with Running it..  But the thing that did bother me is there is no function for turning off the background music  In some areas particularly when I was doing puzzles I muted my computer sound system , But given these two  problems I would not pay it at  its current price of 22.49 Canadian . The partial controller support  icon  makes me also  cautious about recommending this title   at full price as well.   Good points    1  a lot of content  with a lot of available hours of game play   2 great voice acting   3 good graphics   4 easy battle system   5 at least two  mini games after  finishing main story line.  Bad points   1 can not turn off  background music   2  battle system although easy repetitive nature of battles can get annoying  3 seems not to operate on all PCs  4 partial controller support with no signs of square ENEX updating system,      Recommendation  Yes  buy it  but  wait to purchase on sale for about 4 or 5 $ ,  The three  big negatives that  made me suggest a reduced price are  1 unable to turn off background  music   2 seems not to have been given vary many technical modifications for pc  3 partial controller support icon .   4 older abandoned game square Enix  Seems not to be interested in this tittle or support for pc users.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2014
												Final Fantasy XIII-2 is a decent/good JRPG, but a subpar Final Fantasy game.  It continues to tow the line of deviation from what made the core series so great, interesting backstories and adventuring prospects and an overall cohesive main story.  Despite this it is still a better game than FFXIII, and its two main characters actually have significant character development (relative to FFXIII at least). This game although graphically stunning is lacking substance, and albeit improving on some of the linearity of FFXIII it is still not of the same caliber of  other Final Fantasy games and is a forgettable experience. That being said with the exception of some of the developments in FFXIII- Lightning returns aka. 3, much of this game can retroactively be ignored (FFXIII-Lightning returns is arguably the strongest installment in the trilogy, both gameplay and story wise). The story in this game is disjointed so much that playing Metal Gear Solid 4 before any of the others will logically make more sense than some of the components of this game.Gameplay wise, its minimalist approach isn't all bad. You have two main playable characters, Serah and Noel and an captured monster that assists as a third member. The combat as a result offers more complexity than FFXIII-2 albeit still is rudimentary. The exploration involves a variety of areas, not bound by the linear connections that FFXIII's were, and as such you get more opportunities to adventure. You will have an enjoyable experience facing off against the classic assortment of FF foes and a few unique new ones. It should be noted, as stated prior that much of the cast of the previous game is not playable, and Lightning, whom I'd consider as the saving grace in FFXIII has behind the scenes role in this game, despite much of the plot relating to her. Overall the gameplay is worth picking this game up for alone, if you can tolerate the subpar storytelling and disjointed story.I can't recommend this as a Final Fantasy game, but I can recommend it as a JRPG, at its core its still an enjoyable experience that you will find investing many hours in as you continue your adventure in the FFXIII universe.

												I admit that I wasn't warm to the concept of XIII-2 the first time around, and it never won me over in the end. Curiosity got the best of me, and here I find myself, playing a game I never expected to like, and never got into when I tried.The Crystarium is improved from XIII by allowing the grind-happy players to grind to their heart's content and fully develop their characters as soon as the option becomes available; no story-locked stat progression. However... It must be said that my least favorite mechanic of any RPG is the concept of random battles. I find them tedious, annoying, repetitive, and grounds to legally assault whoever decided they were worth including in the gameplay mechanic. When you can just be walking along and some random winged and clawed thing sprouts out of the ground like hopped up kudzu right in front of you with no explanation, and this is a common occurance at the rate of less than 30 seconds per incident, something is UNSPEAKABLY WRONG with your game. The only worse gameplay offense I can specifically name is QTEs, and this game has those, too. A less observant onlooker would assume I have Tourette's.The story is marginally less embarrassing than Final Fantasy X-2's, though no less thoughtless. You can talk all you like about VIII being the entry in the series that discovered recreational uses for household cleaners, but this story is the one that should have warranted an intervention. The only reason I'm happy that it didn't is because I did find enjoyment in Lightning Returns, which I will undoubtedly purchase as soon as it appears on the market, with a very small amount of self-loathing. This series is my guilty pleasure, though this game in particular is the one I will look you in the eye and say, "I swear, this isn't mine; I don't know how it got here".If you use the (all but necessary) community fixes, this is far and away a superior version than the console releases, but I can't recommend it to anyone who didn't already like the console releases. And if you did like the console releases... I am so sorry. Please, pick up Lost Odyssey.TL;DR - This is the best release of a hateful game, but only if you use the community fixes. I'd just rather be playing Lightning Returns.
