There is a great addition of skins in XIII-2 that are taken to the next level in Lightning Returns, something that i rate very highly as i love customization in any game.There is a lack of CG cutscenes in XIII-2 i would have liked a little more than the 2 or 3 they did for the game.Overall i found FFXIII-2 to be a fantastic sequel that is a must play for anyone that enjoyed Final Fantasy XIII, you get the chance to delve further into Lightning and Serah's story, I cant wait to jump into Lightning Returns, this might be one of the best game trilogies ive played, infact this game was the reason i will continue to invest my time and money into the franchise and purchase a PS4 to contine the legacy that is Final Fantasy.Would thank Square Enix again and again and again for porting this to PC.9/10

content:
Posted: March 4, 2015
												Part 2 of the Final Fantasy XIII trilogy starts off fast and gets right into things. The story is nicely carried over from the first XIII title and is generally presented pretty well. We return to familiar faces, along with some new ones.The story starts off quite confusing and you are given tons of info pretty quickly. It may seem messy at first due to alot of unexplained events and the time travel aspect can mix things up a little further. However time travel in XIII-2 is mostly used as a way to get the game world to be opened up a bit and to move away from the linear direction that was FFXIII, from this point of view its done well and doesnt really pose any issues. As the story goes on it gets really intense, i found myself at the edge of my seat a few times.The graphics for the most part seem to be slightly improved over the first game and are really enjoyable. The battle system is fantastic. Its simular to XIII with a bit of a twist with things like the mog clock, allowing you to start off a battle with haste if timed well. There is also the addition of pets and they act as the third member in your party. The Crystarium System is more streamlined and works really well.The performance for some reason isnt as good as XIII and i find myself getting very varied frame rates, this should not happen on a 4000 dollar PC that was purchased in 2015. Overall its not too much of a problem, however it certainly doesnt go unnoticed and its worth mentioning. Hopefully they improve on this for Lightning Returns.Boss fights feel very rewarding and fun. Encounter mechanics are fresh and interesting, this game has one of the most memorable final boss fights ive experienced in ages. There is a fair amount of grinding needed to be done to down the final boss but nothing too crazy, the progression feels right, they really nailed it here. There is a great addition of skins in XIII-2 that are taken to the next level in Lightning Returns, something that i rate very highly as i love customization in any game.There is a lack of CG cutscenes in XIII-2 i would have liked a little more than the 2 or 3 they did for the game.Overall i found FFXIII-2 to be a fantastic sequel that is a must play for anyone that enjoyed Final Fantasy XIII, you get the chance to delve further into Lightning and Serah's story, I cant wait to jump into Lightning Returns, this might be one of the best game trilogies ive played, infact this game was the reason i will continue to invest my time and money into the franchise and purchase a PS4 to contine the legacy that is Final Fantasy.Would thank Square Enix again and again and again for porting this to PC.9/10

content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
												Final Fantasy games have always been tied together by common motifs: crystals, summons, Chocobos, airships, and Yoshitaka Amano's Klimt-esque concept art. In Final Fantasy 13, both towns and exploration were discarded as extraneous trappings, unnecessary to Lightning's mission or - as it was referred to in the game's terminology - her Focus. In 13-2, however, the towns are back with sprawling areas filled with people to talk to for tackling on side quests. In my opinion 13-2 recaptures what was lost in the series's heritage. 13-2 is a game about time traveling, and multiverses. Searh Farron, the main protagonist of this game, is on a quest to search for her lost older sister, Claire Farron.  The idea of including monsters/pets to have their own development trees and can be named, dressed and even fed other captured monsters in order to inherit their abilities is amazing. The customization of developing your characters on a molecular level, then at a squad composition level, can be immensely satisfying. I run this game on high settings, 1080p at average of 50-60fps; however, the fps dips down to 30 in combat, which is bareable. I wish there were more graphics options to tinker with to make this game, but for a console port it is manageable. 8/10

content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												FF13-2 tries to fix what FF13 did wrong, and mostly succeeds.Now you can freely travel between all unlocked locations, interact with NPCs, choose what to say (through this wont have any significant effect on the story). Combat got some nice tweaks: you can change leader in a middle of a fight and add almost any monster in your party. But the best part - developers stopped to threat players like idiots and you'll get access to most features almost from the start.Ofcourse there are some bad things. Enemies appear randomly, just like in classic FF games. And some side quests (for example gathering data on all existing monsters) are practically unfinishable without reading guides (another trademark of classic FF games).Story starts exactly where 13 ends so playing prequel before 13-2 is a must (there is a "beginners primer" in the main menu, but its hardly enough). So, the story... one of the game's features is time travelling, and its even more confusing (at first) and even more epic than before. There are only 2 main characters this time (instead of 6 in FF13) so developers could develop them better and make player more attached to them. Also Caius is easily the best FF antagonist so far.Conclusion. There are 3 games in "lightning saga", 13, 13-2 and lightning returns (13-3). 13-2 is by far the best chapter in this trilogy.

I run this game on high settings, 1080p at average of 50-60fps; however, the fps dips down to 30 in combat, which is bareable. I wish there were more graphics options to tinker with to make this game, but for a console port it is manageable. 8/10

												If you found the story of this games predecessor a little convoluted, you're going to want to give this one a miss. This game takes the incredible story of the original (including the lengthy cut-scenes!) and continues it on a path filled with complex time-travel paradoxes which I'm still not convinced make complete sense.Otherwise, it's definitely worth picking up for any fan of the series. I did feel however that the changes made to the battle and crystarium systems were a little unnecessary and didn't work quite as well as those in the original.Despite being a lot more open and free-roaming than the original (which is commonly referred to as a corridor simulator because of its linearity), this game is approximately half the length of the last, but does offer lots of replayability if you so desire.It's also worth mentioning that this game does thankfully contain the advanced graphics options that were recently introduced with XIII, but does unfortunately suffer from the same performance issues manifested in some pretty serious dips in framerate. The game dosn't come anywhere near being considered as unplayable because of it, it's just something to bear in mind if dropping below 60FPS angers you.Overall, a very solid Final Fantasy game overshadowed slightly by its predecessor, but not enough to stop me from being keen to play the finale to the trilogy when it releases on Steam.PS. I'd also recommend finding the guide in the community page which explains how to patch in Serah's character skin from the original to replace the gaudy bikini skin SE for some reason thought was a good idea.

												About the Story:Haven't played FFXIII but could follow the Story in FFXIII-2 because of the fact that you can read the Story from the first Game in the second from Chapter 1 to 13, which was really great, because the Story in XIII-2 could be a lil bit confusing without if you are really willing to follow the story.About the Collectables:There are 160 fragments which you can get from Sidequests or just by finding them, they will unlock some extra abilities like when you jump, you can jump further by holding the button. Each monster have different abilities and special abilities, which they will learn by leveling them up via monster materials (different from leveling your characters). 												One of my favorite FFs so far, which was totally unexpected since the reviews seemed mixed and I didn't like XIII that much.Good:- Attention to detail with the plot, which makes a lot of efforts to appear coherent and is a lot more memorable than the one from XIII (which is basically a lenghty ultra linear quest which made no sense and lead nowhere). Of course, it's a time paradox based story so you'll find as many plot holes as you want to, but I'd say the writers watched a lot of Doctor Who and it looks decent enough to be enjoyed.- The main paradox in the story is just great, with a Doctor Who style resolution. Awesome.- Real choices with corresponding alternate endings which make sense. And it's a way to escape your doom if you understand the problems with what the main characters are doing ...- The two main characters are annoying and mean good but don't really know what they are doing. Clever. Lightning on the other hand is the best character from the XIII series by far, and they found a nice way to keep her busy while making her look good.- Good combat system, slightly improved from XIII.- The way the side content is blended with the main story (you have to do side missions at some points in the story, explore timelines a bit randomly, etc).- Lots of side timelines and additional missions.- Lots of content.Bad:- Could use a few more locations and one or two major paradox plots in the main story.- Some important side content is gratuitously hard to find without guides (wild artefacts locations ...).- Too grindy to complete the endgame content.- Confusing character advancement (read guides).- The third character in the party are monsters which can be swapped. Nice, but again too grindy and impossible to use correctly without reading wikis and guides. Although they tried to find something original and it's a decent attempt, a regular character would have been better.- Graphics and textures are a big downgrade from XIII. Less budget (but far better game).- Some technical details.

												Definitely better than FFX-2 .... but there are so many better FFs out there. I much preferred FFXIII to the sequel: many moaned that the original was far too linear, which is true, but it had a guiding plot and complex characters with interesting interactions. The sequel suffers from Time Gates (you don't know where/when you're going... means you can have no reason to 'GO' somewhere, you only ever get reasons to 'LEAVE') and only having 2 main characters plus a gimmicky Mog.Quick rundown of the characters:Serah: gets no character development from her supporting role in FFXIIINoel: cross between a cliche of a heartbroken teenager and a cliche of a boy with a fallen hero; neither is developed well. He's protecting Serah because he lost someone and wants to fight Caius because of anger... that's basically everything you get.Mog: "oh isn't he cute..." there, desired reaction achieved. Lightning: watch the trailer on the store page, look at the screenshots... that's about 50% of her presence in the entire game. I'd call her role a cameo but then I'd have nothing to say about Snow, Sazh, Vanille, Fang or the Nora gang...Hope: hey look, one of the original main characters made it intot he game in a meaningful way... too bad they took the most irritating of the characters and took him from an angry/lost kid to the ultimate boy genious. I'm assuming I wasn't the only one to miss the groundwork to suggest he wasn't just average intelligence... probably because it isn't there. He doesn't even get any noticeable character development: assume he's just a cliche child genious and you won't go far wrong.In fact Hope's role in this game is simply a lazy plot device... same goes for almost every solution to every part of every section of the game: do random things and the answer to your problem drops straight in your path. If they'd called this "FFXIII-Deus Ex Machina" I could have understood that, but as it is I just found it robbed any sort of unifying force to the story.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2016
												After finally finding fixes for the issues I was having, I can now easily recommend this game. I'm not stingy about framerate, so playing this game at a steady, unmoving 30fps feels really nice, in comparison to the wonky 10fps-60fps I was having with the framerate unlocker.Here's what I did: I first tried the framerate unlocker, which, as I said, was giving me some rather inconsistent framerate, among several other issues such as lip-sync going off. After that, I used a program called Nvidia Inspector (there's another program called RadeonPro for AMD cards) to limit my framerate to 30fps and v-sync to 1/2 refresh rate. My game was working perfectly after that, though the rain glitch still existed. After picking up the fix for that, I can enjoy the game fully, completely, how it was intended to be played. If you follow those steps, this PC port is definitely the best version of the game. Coming with most of the console version's DLC, and now with Japanese audio (which in my opinion, is vastly superior to the English audio), this game is a great experience that improves upon the original XIII in every way I can think of. While I haven't beaten it yet, the story is great so far, with interesting characters, good graphics, fun gameplay, ear-♥♥♥♥♥♥ic soundtrack, and fantastic atmosphere. I can see why Famitsu gave this game a 40/40, it's rather incredible. The XIII series is criminally underrated by "fans" of Final Fantasy, but if you like JRPGs with high production values and go in with an open mind (the story isn't told to you completely, you have to figure some of it out yourself), you'll like this game a lot.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
												FFXIII-2 is such a good game that it almost makes me like FFXIII in retrospect. Almost.First, let's just get the elephant in the room out of the way: yes, this port is terribly optimized. It may work fine for some, but I played at 30fps with drops, with is really pretty abysmal. The only thing this has over playing on console is resolution and the ability to use the Japanese audio. The Japanese audio, by the way, is fantastic.So now on to the good. I played through FFXIII and really hated the experience by the end and still consider it the worst entry in the franchise. Then this game comes along and basically fixes every problem I had with the original.Combat:- Paradigm switching is now instant! A no brainer change, really, but it changes the pace of battle so much when you don't have to watch the camera stupidly focus in on every party member one at a time for each paradigm shift.- You can now tame wild monsters and have them fight along side you. This not only goes a long way towards offering the player choice in how to compose their party early on, but it's also just a lot of fun finding badass or adorable monsters and taming them.-The game just generally utilizes the game mechanics much more. I was forced to rapidly switch between paradigms and change up my party compositions SO much more than the original.-Boss fights typically include QTE's to finish off the fight. Some might take issue with this but I liked them and it made beating bosses feel really satisfying. Reminded me of Bayonetta.-Enemies no longer appear in the field all the time, but rather randomly show up in circle around you as you walk around. This isn't reeeaaally a positive or negative change, but what IS better is that you now have a dedicated attack button to get the drop on enemies instead of runnung around in circles like an idiot tryng to run into enemies from behind like in the original. -Actually, there is a negative to be mentioned here: difficulty spikes. I have no problem with challenging games but when a section or boss comes out of nowhere and just wipes the floor with you repeatedly it tends to raise an eyebrow. This thankfully only happened to me twice (once in the middle, and then final batshit crazy boss), but it was more than a little annoying.General Gameplay:The original game had you do 2 things and 2 things only: walk forward and fight enemies. FFXIII-2 not only gets you up and running with all the game mechanics MUCH quicker, but generally has a greater amount of variety in it's gameplay, including:- Actual sidequests! And lots of 'em! - NPC's to talk to and interact with! Lots of those too!- Branching pathways and areas that aren't a simple straight line! - Monsters to tame and level up! Fight with a chocobo at your side!- You have an adorable Moogle companion who you can throw (yes, throw) to reach far away treasure. A small but hilarious addition.- The crystarium has been changed. It's still a pretty linear affair, but every time you fill up a full grid or screen or whatever, you can choose a big reward like adding a new section to the ATB guage or even unlocking a new role.Story/characters/world:- I was completely sick of most of the characters in FFXIII by the time I was through with it. Serah and Noel are, thankfully, handled in a much better fashion. I found Serah to be likeable from the get go,  and while her motivations aren't really that deep ("I just want to see my sister again!") she's characterized really well and her sincerity is really charming. Then Noel is like FF's version of Riku, minus the being a d*ck to the main character part. Both have really solid voice acting whether playing in Japanese or English.- This game is also pretty dark, which might not be what you expect from looking at it. The farther and farther into the future you travel the more hopeless things become. This sense of desperation, to me, is the heart of Final Fantasy.- On a similar note, the time travelling is a lot of fun. Seeing how the world and characters change depending on what time period or even timeline they're in is really interesting. There's a good chance you'll get sick of hearing the word "paradox", though. You've been warned.Graphics/sound:- The soundtrack is phenominal. The original certainly wasn't dragging it's feet in this department but I feel like it fell a bit short of pulling off a "different" sounding FF score. XIII-2 absolutely pulls it off. The three composers have put together an awesome collection of beautiful tracks ranging from the classic FF sounds, to some more electronically infused numbers and,  best of all, a handfull of tracks that include vocals. The New Bodhum theme alone sets this score apart.- The game's a looker, no doubt about that. Special mention goes to the animation however, as I think Square is really great at animating their characters and especially faces.There is one more negative however, and that's how the game handles it's ending. To see the "real" ending you have to play a (thankfully included) DLC chapter that is incredibly tedious and feels entirely divorced from the whole experience. It's weird that Square would get such a huge amount of things right in this game and then bork up the delivery of the ending. Yeah. Just weird.That aside, I can't recommend this game enough. If you already liked the first, then you robably didn't need any convincing anyway, but if you are like me and hated the original, then I have to urge you to give this one a shot. It's not often that a studio puts in this much effort into fixing a game, so when they do I think they deserve to be rewarded.

												A good game, but a very, very bad PC port.  If you're interested in this game and have a PS3 or 360, i'd recommend playing it on one of those systems.Storyline;An incredibly tragic time-travel based storyline.  It does it very well (in my opinion) and is the strongest game, story-wise, in the Lightning Saga.Gameplay;It has a streamlined, simplified version of FF13's ATB battle system.  Serah and Noel are your two static characters, with your third character being a tamed monster of a fixed role.  You can have up to 3 differnet monsters in your "Party Pack" that you can use to make paradigms.  Still a good system, but I prefer FF13's.Difficulty;This is a pretty big one for me.  There's almost no difficulty at all here. The superbosses, as you might expect them to be, aren't a challenge at all.  I came across both of them while doing sidequests with no preperation at all and was able to defeat them with ease.  I didn't even know they were supposed to be "superbosses." The only difficulty in this game comes from fighting the poor frame rate and the DLC Colosseum.Music;It has a mix of original songs and songs from FF13.  There are some songs made for 13-2 that are nice, but the majority of them are quite bad.

Posted: April 8, 2015
												Remember that like any modern Final Fantasy game, you may just hate it at first glance and I respect that decision.TL;DR below.Story-  This story is full of plot-holes and makes no sense.  Final Fantasy XII's story is a Godsend in comparison to this.  Imagine Final Fantasy XIII's story but with time travel that goes against all of the modern time travel conventions.  It is really only there to get the characters together for a new adventure.  You should not be playing this game for the story.Exploration-  While still somewhat linear, there are hidden chests placed throughout the world that you can find.  You are also able to accept quests in the field.  Completion of these quests will cut down on grind time because they give you EXP (Crystarium Points).  You can travel between the different areas of the game in the Historia Crux, a menu showing all of the points of time you can travel to.  This menu allows you to reset areas, battling bosses again and gathering treasures you might have missed.  Enemies show up at random on the field, but you are given a short period of time to run away from them or get an early attack on them.Combat-  In combat, you have a bar that is split into several segments that fills over time.  Battle commands can be attached to the segments of the gauge.  You can choose to use the entirety of your gauge at once, or use moves as the bar fills up.  Serah and Noel can be assigned classes and switch between these classes in combat.  This is where the meat of the battle strategy comes from.  You are able to have a Pokemon-esque monster accompany you in battle.  This monster also has a class which will help balance out your team.  The way the class system works still goes over my head, but I think that combat is enjoyable nonetheless.Optimization- This game will run like garbage on YOUR PC.  I DON'T CARE IF YOU HAVE A TITAN X, THE GAME IS JUST BROKEN.  EXPECT 30 FPS AT ALL TIMES.TL;DR, like most modern Final Fantasy games you will love it or you will hate it.  The story is meaningless, but the gameplay is enjoyable.6.5/10 mediocre, would bluescreen while playing again.

												About the Story:Haven't played FFXIII but could follow the Story in FFXIII-2 because of the fact that you can read the Story from the first Game in the second from Chapter 1 to 13, which was really great, because the Story in XIII-2 could be a lil bit confusing without if you are really willing to follow the story.About the Collectables:There are 160 fragments which you can get from Sidequests or just by finding them, they will unlock some extra abilities like when you jump, you can jump further by holding the button. The Monster Combat System:You can *catch* some monsters like Tonberry, which will fight beside you and your other team mate. Each monster have different abilities and special abilities, which they will learn by leveling them up via monster materials (different from leveling your characters). You can also infuse a monster with another monster to get them their abilities like +XXXstrength.(This will delete the infused monster, but you can still get it back by catching it again).Linear Gameplay yes/no?:I can pretty much say that this game isn't linear at all, you can do whatever you want to do once you entered the first episode. If you do not want to follow the story part, then you can just do some sidequests or search for items. Of course there are some sidequests which will get unlocked after finishing the game, but still good for people who do not want to follow the story immediatly.Does this game have long time motivation?:In my opinion, this FF is really enjoyable even if you already have beaten the game. I was at the final boss in like 29 hours, but decided to do some sidequests and then beat the boss after a total of 44 hours. Also I already played over 50+ hours after finishing the game, because there are some things like the Coliseum, which can pretty much take your time pretty fast. The bosses there are some well-known FF bosses and are challenging if you do not know or have tactics to defeat them.Also... you can play poker as Sazh... that is.... awesome? :PNegative thingys?:Yes, there is one thing which is negative.Sometimes the FPS goes to like 20...BUT I did and I do not care if it does. You should totally play this game!Overall:Almost 100 Hours of playtime and still 3 bosses left + 7 collectables. Fav. FF so far with FFX :3!

content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
												While I personally felt largely positive towards Final Fantasy XIII, this installment in the XIII series has left me feeling mostly frustrated and disappointed. Lightning was the focal point and poster girl of XIII but this time around you instead play as her sister Serah. Normally I’d have no problem with the idea of a spin off focusing on a different character however Serah was probably one of the least interesting characters in the original game and I was never really thinking “Hey, I sure would like to play as her”. Unfortunately the supporting cast is pretty lacking and the second member of your party “Noel” is nothing to write home about either. This also leads me to my next problem with XIII-2 which is that you only have two members in your party (the third slot being allocated to a monster of your choice). The plot is one of the most convoluted and dull time travel stories I’ve yet to see in a long while and at no point did this installment really ever feel warranted to me. The gameplay and progression is changed up a bit this time. The much criticized linearity of XIII has been somewhat remedied by adding branching levels which gives the player more options as to how they’d like to progress. The levels mostly feel pretty empty and dull with some nice scenery here or there. Lifeless npc’s inhabit most of them providing lackluster side quests to keep you from progressing too quickly. My biggest grievance however is that this port does not feel like it was given very much love or care. Your mileage may vary but even after installing an unofficial patch I suffered a lot of frame drops and low fps in the open world segments (however menus and battles mostly remained smooth). This doesn’t seem excusable when my PC is capable of running games like GTAV and The Witcher 3 on reasonably high settings at consistent frame rates. I was fortunately able to tough it out through most of the slower segments of the game. I should probably mention what I actually did like about the game. You get a lot of the same quality scenery and pretty cutscenes that you should be familiar with from XIII. It’s got the same easy and action based combat that I enjoyed from the last installment. The music is varied from the usual pretty tunes you expect from Final Fantasy to some perplexingly strange songs (Wild Chocobo theme, anyone?). The game doesn’t seem to always take itself too seriously which is fine by me. Be ready for some goofy anime nonsense. I could only really recommend this game on very particular circumstance. While this review is mostly negative I did however enjoy a good portion of my time with it and for the price I felt satisfied. It’s a pretty bad port and I’d imagine most wouldn’t have the patience to complete the game because of this. If the performance was improved I’d easily recommend it on the basis of an impulse buy during a sale however you may just be better off skipping this installment. There’s a lot of better Final Fantasy games on Steam.

												Bought this back on the PS3 when it first came out but couldn't get into it. Tried it again a few years later, pushed past the slightly dull opening few hours and now can't put it down. It's an interesting concept: travelling through time to try to change history, visiting alternate versions of the same places on different timelines - as well as the obligatory 'save the world' theme. Sure, it still has that slght repetitiveness that FFXIII had, but this time the world at least feels more open and not so much a 'walk down this corridor and fight lots of enemies ad infinitum' feel that its predecessor had.I know there are meant to be issues with the port, and my FPS fluctuates wildly between 20-60 all the time, but I can't say I've actually noticed any difference when it does (i.e. lagging or screen-tearing), so can't comment on the actual issues themselves.All in all, this is a more interesting game than FFXIII (minus some of its most interesting characters in Lightning and Fang, for me) and I'm looking forward to completing it so I can finally play 'Lightning Returns'. Even if you got bored of XIII, I'd recommend giving this a go, especially for the sale price.

												I would say this episode is a really well made game, even I just play for like 50 minutes. For some people; this story might not be interesting, but it still have some fun parts to play with. I'll give it some examples:- First of all, one thing is not going change is this game has an excellent graphic, no doubt it. I can adjust the screen size resolution same as FF13 Lightning Returns up to 1920x1080p and shadow resolution up to 8120x8120 before the game starts, which is really high definition. I found when I put my shadow resolution into 8120x8120, everthing seems like too lagging, almost gone to frozen. I was not able to turn off game, then started panicking. After like 10 minutes, I shut down my PC and restarted again. Listen carefully, I can hardly to move the mouse to the shut down button. I found myself quite silly sometime, I should have made sure my PC can run that level before I go to adjust the resolutions. As a result, I just wanted to find that setting how high resolution my PC can handle itself.One thing I would like to suggest is making a game on a PC should have an Exit button, then player can go exit the game easily rather than clicking the window tab to go out to the window bar and close the game app or going into Steam app to play a game and closing the game on Steam app. Just my opinion sharing.- Second of all, I want to be clear I am not a spoiler, I just want to talk about the battle combat in this episode. In this episode, the battle combat still keep the old version of the function the most which I feel a bit not functional like Lightning Returns, it would be good to have some movements controling by the players, let players feel they're actually controling what Lightning is going to move next. At the same time, I found a new battle combat, which was Cinematic Actions". I found Cinematic Actions quite fun to play with, it's also about testing how fast you can react. I think Cinemtic Actions makes you more exciting and what makes players to expect something that is cool and fun would happen. I have a thought of this Cinematic Actions, if this could put it into Final Fantasy 7, to me I think, it would be really epic! Myself quite like this kind of cinematic actions, it is also really making a game come to life. As usual, I would recommend this game to my friends! Thanks the director and the group of game developers for making this three long episodes for every player here included me! 												I gotta say I like it so far. After three hours it's got my attention better than FF13. I like how the maps aren't just linear with small pockets that obviously hold item chests. I like the NPC interaction, even if it is just flavor. Overall, I think the addition of more explorable map areas is a vast improvement over FF13.My only beef is the controller. It says Partial Controller supprt, but I can play just fine with my controller... Except my left stick doesn't work, gotta use the D-pad. X=A. A=B. B=X. Y=Y.  LB and LT equal LB and RB, not sure which is which. Rt is RT, not sure what RB is or does yet.The controller misfires aren't that big a deal, once you figure them out, they might♥♥♥♥♥♥you off at the start, but once you get them down, it's alright. Haven't really had any framerates issues, a stutter here and there, but nothing I'm gonna get up in arms about.Overall I like this better than 13. Story is more engaging, world is more explorable, I just got into the meat and potatoes, if you will, of the combat, and I like it better. I like how the general combat system is the same, but the third party member tweak, and tuning, are what make it awesome. Graphics and soundtrack are pretty much what you would expect from a Final Fantasy title. In a word, Amazing.I'd give it 9/10 based on the three hours I've played so far. This review, and that rating are both subject to change. The controller thing is a pretty big minus, even though it's pretty easy to adjust to.Edit 03/09/16: I love the monster system. The way they worked it into the Paradigm System, effing awesome. It let's you focus teh PC's one one or two roles, then use a Monster you've levelled to pick up the slack. On my first playthrough, I've got the PC's doing a Main Role and Secondary Role. Like I'm leveling Raveger har, and Sabateur a little on one. The other is Commando and Sentinel. I might put a little Synergist on the second one, don't know if or wehn I'll get a monster that can buff.In short, six hours in, I EFFING LOVE this game. I haven't had a game grab me like this since Fallout 3. I have to force myself to stop playing so that I can go to bed for work the next day.

												After finally finding fixes for the issues I was having, I can now easily recommend this game. I'm not stingy about framerate, so playing this game at a steady, unmoving 30fps feels really nice, in comparison to the wonky 10fps-60fps I was having with the framerate unlocker.Here's what I did: I first tried the framerate unlocker, which, as I said, was giving me some rather inconsistent framerate, among several other issues such as lip-sync going off. After that, I used a program called Nvidia Inspector (there's another program called RadeonPro for AMD cards) to limit my framerate to 30fps and v-sync to 1/2 refresh rate. My game was working perfectly after that, though the rain glitch still existed. After picking up the fix for that, I can enjoy the game fully, completely, how it was intended to be played. If you follow those steps, this PC port is definitely the best version of the game. Coming with most of the console version's DLC, and now with Japanese audio (which in my opinion, is vastly superior to the English audio), this game is a great experience that improves upon the original XIII in every way I can think of. While I haven't beaten it yet, the story is great so far, with interesting characters, good graphics, fun gameplay, ear-♥♥♥♥♥♥ic soundtrack, and fantastic atmosphere. I can see why Famitsu gave this game a 40/40, it's rather incredible. The XIII series is criminally underrated by "fans" of Final Fantasy, but if you like JRPGs with high production values and go in with an open mind (the story isn't told to you completely, you have to figure some of it out yourself), you'll like this game a lot.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
												FFXIII-2 is such a good game that it almost makes me like FFXIII in retrospect. Almost.First, let's just get the elephant in the room out of the way: yes, this port is terribly optimized. It may work fine for some, but I played at 30fps with drops, with is really pretty abysmal. The only thing this has over playing on console is resolution and the ability to use the Japanese audio. The Japanese audio, by the way, is fantastic.So now on to the good. I played through FFXIII and really hated the experience by the end and still consider it the worst entry in the franchise. Then this game comes along and basically fixes every problem I had with the original.Combat:- Paradigm switching is now instant! A no brainer change, really, but it changes the pace of battle so much when you don't have to watch the camera stupidly focus in on every party member one at a time for each paradigm shift.- You can now tame wild monsters and have them fight along side you. This not only goes a long way towards offering the player choice in how to compose their party early on, but it's also just a lot of fun finding badass or adorable monsters and taming them.-The game just generally utilizes the game mechanics much more. I was forced to rapidly switch between paradigms and change up my party compositions SO much more than the original.-Boss fights typically include QTE's to finish off the fight. Some might take issue with this but I liked them and it made beating bosses feel really satisfying. Reminded me of Bayonetta.-Enemies no longer appear in the field all the time, but rather randomly show up in circle around you as you walk around. This isn't reeeaaally a positive or negative change, but what IS better is that you now have a dedicated attack button to get the drop on enemies instead of runnung around in circles like an idiot tryng to run into enemies from behind like in the original. -Actually, there is a negative to be mentioned here: difficulty spikes. I have no problem with challenging games but when a section or boss comes out of nowhere and just wipes the floor with you repeatedly it tends to raise an eyebrow. This thankfully only happened to me twice (once in the middle, and then final batshit crazy boss), but it was more than a little annoying.General Gameplay:The original game had you do 2 things and 2 things only: walk forward and fight enemies. FFXIII-2 not only gets you up and running with all the game mechanics MUCH quicker, but generally has a greater amount of variety in it's gameplay, including:- Actual sidequests! And lots of 'em! - NPC's to talk to and interact with! Lots of those too!- Branching pathways and areas that aren't a simple straight line! - Monsters to tame and level up! Fight with a chocobo at your side!- You have an adorable Moogle companion who you can throw (yes, throw) to reach far away treasure. A small but hilarious addition.- The crystarium has been changed. It's still a pretty linear affair, but every time you fill up a full grid or screen or whatever, you can choose a big reward like adding a new section to the ATB guage or even unlocking a new role.Story/characters/world:- I was completely sick of most of the characters in FFXIII by the time I was through with it. Serah and Noel are, thankfully, handled in a much better fashion. I found Serah to be likeable from the get go,  and while her motivations aren't really that deep ("I just want to see my sister again!") she's characterized really well and her sincerity is really charming. Then Noel is like FF's version of Riku, minus the being a d*ck to the main character part. Both have really solid voice acting whether playing in Japanese or English.- This game is also pretty dark, which might not be what you expect from looking at it. The farther and farther into the future you travel the more hopeless things become. This sense of desperation, to me, is the heart of Final Fantasy.- On a similar note, the time travelling is a lot of fun. Seeing how the world and characters change depending on what time period or even timeline they're in is really interesting. There's a good chance you'll get sick of hearing the word "paradox", though. You've been warned.Graphics/sound:- The soundtrack is phenominal. The original certainly wasn't dragging it's feet in this department but I feel like it fell a bit short of pulling off a "different" sounding FF score. XIII-2 absolutely pulls it off. The three composers have put together an awesome collection of beautiful tracks ranging from the classic FF sounds, to some more electronically infused numbers and,  best of all, a handfull of tracks that include vocals. The New Bodhum theme alone sets this score apart.- The game's a looker, no doubt about that. Special mention goes to the animation however, as I think Square is really great at animating their characters and especially faces.There is one more negative however, and that's how the game handles it's ending. To see the "real" ending you have to play a (thankfully included) DLC chapter that is incredibly tedious and feels entirely divorced from the whole experience. It's weird that Square would get such a huge amount of things right in this game and then bork up the delivery of the ending. Yeah. Just weird.That aside, I can't recommend this game enough. If you already liked the first, then you robably didn't need any convincing anyway, but if you are like me and hated the original, then I have to urge you to give this one a shot. It's not often that a studio puts in this much effort into fixing a game, so when they do I think they deserve to be rewarded.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												To me, it's unfortunate that the string of Final Fantasy games that were released with the main number of XIII are written off as lousy games. Yes, they all have flaws, but that doesn't mean you can't enjoy playing them. FF XIII-2 is a prime example of such a game.When you release a sequel, the game will inevitably be compared to the source material and I'll do such a thing here as well. While I personally enjoyed XIII, it has received its fair share of critizism. The complaints were mainly aimed at the long tutorial sequence, the linear gameplay and the convoluted story. It also had some other issues, such as a long transition time between the first paradigm shift (the battle system in these games) and the sometimes uninteresting or downright annoying characters.Square seemed to have done something about most complaints with the sequel. For starters, the opening level (playing as Lightning, the protagonist of the first game) is pretty interesting and while the tutorial sequence with Serah (Lightning's little sister) is a bit tedious again, it doesn't drag on for hours to come. Besides that, there are many ways to explore and revisit different regions and they give the player more options to choose from and more routes to follow. This is probably the biggest change compared to its predecessor and it really helps the game.I myself embrace most of the changes they made compared to the first game. Like I said, I enjoyed XIII, but most annoyances I had with the first game are removed. For instance, it took me about 60 hours to finish XIII and a few sidequests but it took me ANOTHER 65 hours to wrap up every achievement in the game, including having to grind the toughest enemy of the game in the hope of getting an item I needed for every weapon available. It's way less tedious to complete everything in XIII-2, with the chocobo rider and slot machine achievements being the exceptions. Most battles are now avoidable, which is also a step up from XIII. They also improved and simplified the leveling system, sped up the first paradigm shift and gave us the opportunity to use monsters as part of the team.Another feature they added in this game is the possibility of alternate endings. While some can be found and viewed during your regular playthrough, most can only be seen after beating the final boss. That also brings us to the post-game content. There are many fragments in each world that serve as a sorts of collectibles. Some serve a purpose, for instance opening a portal to a new and unexplored world or timezone. Some are easier to find than others. The alternative endings you view also net you a fragment for that region. With the time map you use to explore the worlds, it's easy to see if you have found every fragment in that world and time zone. What's even more interesting is that you have the power to "rewind" a certain section of the game, meaning you can go back and play that part of the story as if you had never set foot on the world before. This serves as a fun way to kill time and make sure you have explored every nook and cranny of the game.The biggest drawback of XIII is the story. While XIII's story was convoluted and complicated if you didn't take the time to read TONS of story-related content in your menu, XIII-2's story is just too simple. Every problem in the world has to do with time paradoxes and time-travel (which is a key part of the gameplay as well) and they can all be resolved by fixing said paradoxes. That's as straightforward as it can get. The game has a really interesting enemy in the form of Caius Ballad, though he's mainly made interesting by some stellar voice acting by Liam O'Brien. The fights with him are especially very epic and the first battle with Caius proves a hefty challenge if you don't level up some more. It's too bad he didn't get as much screen time he deserved.That being said, the game is still very much enjoyable. If you can look past the obvious plotholes, or timeholes if you will (badun tss), XIII-2 will give you a fun time exploring the wonderful world of Pulse in an abundance of time zones. The music, the graphics and especially the gameplay make for a game I wouldn't mind completing over and over. I hope you'll give it a chance - and enjoy it as much as I did!

												A good game, but a very, very bad PC port.  If you're interested in this game and have a PS3 or 360, i'd recommend playing it on one of those systems.Storyline;An incredibly tragic time-travel based storyline.  It does it very well (in my opinion) and is the strongest game, story-wise, in the Lightning Saga.Gameplay;It has a streamlined, simplified version of FF13's ATB battle system.  Serah and Noel are your two static characters, with your third character being a tamed monster of a fixed role.  You can have up to 3 differnet monsters in your "Party Pack" that you can use to make paradigms.  Still a good system, but I prefer FF13's.Difficulty;This is a pretty big one for me.  There's almost no difficulty at all here. The superbosses, as you might expect them to be, aren't a challenge at all.  I came across both of them while doing sidequests with no preperation at all and was able to defeat them with ease.  I didn't even know they were supposed to be "superbosses." The only difficulty in this game comes from fighting the poor frame rate and the DLC Colosseum.Music;It has a mix of original songs and songs from FF13.  There are some songs made for 13-2 that are nice, but the majority of them are quite bad.

content:
Posted: March 13
												Review on Final Fantasy XIII-2   1. Intro.   2. Problems/Why this is Honestly Not Recommended.   3. Advice and Recommended to play.   4. Finale. 1. Intro.  First, If you Have Windows 10, dont buy this. Most problems are held buy people with Windows 10 but not held by others. It isn't properly supported, dont get it.  Next, I've played this game for 200+ hrs,By saying this, most gamers understand the amount of experience I have with this story-based game that can be finished in 40-70 hrs, compared to an angry review after 2-10hrs of blindly butting heads with the terrible *edit* bad, port. This is a review by someone who has played through this game for a significant amount of time.  2. Why this should Honestly Not be Recommended,   a) This review is from a gamer that played this PC version for months I want to say that I Honestly think this is a great game brought from the PS3, but the performance put out by the port isnt very good. Unless your PC runs at some amazing stats, Its hard to play at anything other than the base image settings and the FPS is still pretty bad.   b) One of the Biggest problems happens during Cinematic Cutscenes, your game will try to load a lot of new information and also try to autosave which worked on the console, however the longer you play the game, the more information the game will tryto process. i.e. completed/ongoing quests, certain events that need to be implemented, and the biggest thing are Savestates which will take a significant amount of processinging all occuring in the small amount of time oof moving between the world you are in, and the World Select. Whenever you transition between worlds, which in mid to late game is a significant amout of times, this game will try to load , process and save all at the same time. During the early game this problem isn't very apparent, but at 40+ hrs, the change becomes much more apparent, eventually past 100+ hrs triggering even small cutscenes, which automatically load and autosave at the same time, will often crash the game, causing whatever progress was made to all feel worthless. While the game itself is fun and engaging, with a great story, and  good design, the PC version has its issues.   c) Occasionally, if the amount of data in your Savestate is fairly high, (100+ hrs worth, but possibly less.) Steamcloud, where all default savestates are managed will randomly"move", essentually deleting them. Meaning that they are no longer accessable to you from your Main Menu or found any where in your PC's Files, leaving only the New Game option available. 3. Recommended and advice  a) Steamcloud shouldn't be turned on while playing this game. There is a warning on the Launcher stating that processing may take longer because of Steamclouds synchronisation with the servor. The fact that there is any kind of Warning on the launcher should be a clear indicator that there is a problem.There will be planty of times that SteamCloud will start synchronizing and crash your game. It would be best if you played this while in offline mode, the trophies may be fun to get but if you want to enjoy this game its not worth the risk's.  b)  Make sure you create an independent Save file location that is not managed by Steam. Frequently delete unnecessary savestates, and you can keep the amount of information processed farther on in the game to a more manageable amount.  c)  Keep your settings low, again this port isn't the most capable, during the early game when the amount of data being processed is rather low, it should be fine to raise the settings to whatever your PC can handle, just remember that even if your game runs fairly smoothly later on in the game, cutscenes and loading processing requirements will grow at a steepening curve. Whatever you can do to help your game run smoothly even at the cost of quality is worth it.  d) Look up Crysterium and Monster Guides before you leave the first world. Like others in the FF Series this Game will seem fairly easy at first, but even moreso then prievious games, it will absolutly punish unknowing mistakes, stopping you from even reaching the late game, let alone post game. Leveling the Crysterium (Essentually Levels) is an irreversable process, that if left to a novice will cause any small mistakes in building your character, that might not be so relevent early on, will become devestating to those that want to enjoy the late game.  d.i)  Monsters play a huge role in this game, and just like with Crysterium, are a major part of the game that will eventually be the focus of your team, as in they will be the party member that you recruit, train, and carry you through the game.  d.ii) While its not neccesary to look up guides on these to succeed, it is reccommended, finding the Hidden Monster(s), that can become the Gods to carry you through late game and final bosses. Finding the correct Infusiuon Recipes to build them into said Gods, finding which monsters youll need to grind for in certain conditons. And realising before you kill certain indespensible and unrespawnable monsters that you actually need them and should save in front of them and soft reset if you dont get it until you do.4.  Altogether this is a great game. I would say that this Port has to many problems that havent been corrected, and can only be managed by the user who pays the full price for this, but then has to do the providers job of making it usable in order to actually play this. After playing over 200+ hrs on the PC version of this game I can say that for those who still want to purchase this after reading this review, follow the above recommended advice, and hopefully someday this game will be Patched enough That I can honestly Recommend this to prospecting FF Players.

(still got migraines from FF10 & FF10-2)- No need for level grindingCons:- Weak Characters (Noel's story isn't believable)- Loading screens drive me insane- Weak story because of main characters.I wish there was a Mixed button, A simple Yes or No recommendation is Hard to give for this game for me its a 5/10. so recommendation is only YES because of fanboy issem and that it isn't all bad.

content:
Posted: March 13
												Review on Final Fantasy XIII-2   1. Intro.   2. Problems/Why this is Honestly Not Recommended.   3. Advice and Recommended to play.   4. Finale. 1. Intro.  First, If you Have Windows 10, dont buy this. Most problems are held buy people with Windows 10 but not held by others. It isn't properly supported, dont get it.  Next, I've played this game for 200+ hrs,By saying this, most gamers understand the amount of experience I have with this story-based game that can be finished in 40-70 hrs, compared to an angry review after 2-10hrs of blindly butting heads with the terrible *edit* bad, port. This is a review by someone who has played through this game for a significant amount of time.  2. Why this should Honestly Not be Recommended,   a) This review is from a gamer that played this PC version for months I want to say that I Honestly think this is a great game brought from the PS3, but the performance put out by the port isnt very good. Unless your PC runs at some amazing stats, Its hard to play at anything other than the base image settings and the FPS is still pretty bad.   b) One of the Biggest problems happens during Cinematic Cutscenes, your game will try to load a lot of new information and also try to autosave which worked on the console, however the longer you play the game, the more information the game will tryto process. i.e. completed/ongoing quests, certain events that need to be implemented, and the biggest thing are Savestates which will take a significant amount of processinging all occuring in the small amount of time oof moving between the world you are in, and the World Select. Whenever you transition between worlds, which in mid to late game is a significant amout of times, this game will try to load , process and save all at the same time. During the early game this problem isn't very apparent, but at 40+ hrs, the change becomes much more apparent, eventually past 100+ hrs triggering even small cutscenes, which automatically load and autosave at the same time, will often crash the game, causing whatever progress was made to all feel worthless. While the game itself is fun and engaging, with a great story, and  good design, the PC version has its issues.   c) Occasionally, if the amount of data in your Savestate is fairly high, (100+ hrs worth, but possibly less.) Steamcloud, where all default savestates are managed will randomly"move", essentually deleting them. Meaning that they are no longer accessable to you from your Main Menu or found any where in your PC's Files, leaving only the New Game option available. 3. Recommended and advice  a) Steamcloud shouldn't be turned on while playing this game. There is a warning on the Launcher stating that processing may take longer because of Steamclouds synchronisation with the servor. The fact that there is any kind of Warning on the launcher should be a clear indicator that there is a problem.There will be planty of times that SteamCloud will start synchronizing and crash your game. It would be best if you played this while in offline mode, the trophies may be fun to get but if you want to enjoy this game its not worth the risk's.  b)  Make sure you create an independent Save file location that is not managed by Steam. Frequently delete unnecessary savestates, and you can keep the amount of information processed farther on in the game to a more manageable amount.  c)  Keep your settings low, again this port isn't the most capable, during the early game when the amount of data being processed is rather low, it should be fine to raise the settings to whatever your PC can handle, just remember that even if your game runs fairly smoothly later on in the game, cutscenes and loading processing requirements will grow at a steepening curve. Whatever you can do to help your game run smoothly even at the cost of quality is worth it.  d) Look up Crysterium and Monster Guides before you leave the first world. Like others in the FF Series this Game will seem fairly easy at first, but even moreso then prievious games, it will absolutly punish unknowing mistakes, stopping you from even reaching the late game, let alone post game. Leveling the Crysterium (Essentually Levels) is an irreversable process, that if left to a novice will cause any small mistakes in building your character, that might not be so relevent early on, will become devestating to those that want to enjoy the late game.  d.i)  Monsters play a huge role in this game, and just like with Crysterium, are a major part of the game that will eventually be the focus of your team, as in they will be the party member that you recruit, train, and carry you through the game.  d.ii) While its not neccesary to look up guides on these to succeed, it is reccommended, finding the Hidden Monster(s), that can become the Gods to carry you through late game and final bosses. Finding the correct Infusiuon Recipes to build them into said Gods, finding which monsters youll need to grind for in certain conditons. And realising before you kill certain indespensible and unrespawnable monsters that you actually need them and should save in front of them and soft reset if you dont get it until you do.4.  Altogether this is a great game. I would say that this Port has to many problems that havent been corrected, and can only be managed by the user who pays the full price for this, but then has to do the providers job of making it usable in order to actually play this. After playing over 200+ hrs on the PC version of this game I can say that for those who still want to purchase this after reading this review, follow the above recommended advice, and hopefully someday this game will be Patched enough That I can honestly Recommend this to prospecting FF Players.

												Just to first note, yes this game is buggy for the PC, but this is one of the best FF games. You can get around a lot of issues limiting your cores to real cores if you have a Intel CPU, if you're running AMD you should be fine. Then setting the game to window not fullscreen and use "Borderless Gaming" to achive fullscreen.  I've had the game crash very little since doing that. There are various fixes through the community you can look into. I'm running an Intel i7 4790k with a R9 390, my FPS is normally 60 but this game does drop frames even if you do the fixes. I'm not holding my breath for Sqaure to come back and patch this game, there isn't much of a point now considering the game's age. Now to the actual game. Overall I've really enjoyed this FF a lot, the improvements they made to the gameplay aspect really improved it. I like the fact that there are puzzles and almost a "treasure hunt" throughout the game. The characters are really likeable, which is something I think the XIII series get's looked over for. The story is actually really good, it's not confusing if you have half a brain, I saw some reviews critiquing that. You can easily get about 30 hours on this game, right now I have 29-ish and I haven't even completed the story. You're rewarded for exploring (much like XIII) and taking your time in this game, so do so.Game can kinda be a press "x" simulator at points like it's predecessor, but the leveling up system in this one provided more a challenge as well as your Paradigm Shift and ATB playing more of a factor in this one. I also like the addition of having monsters that fight with you.All in all this game isn't perfect for the PC, but it still get's a 5/5 for me for the actual game.And finally it's got Mog. :3
